{"document": "Eddie Murphy wrote a letter to parents of the Foundation for Education and Development, which operates near City of Bristol, saying government cuts had left it at \"crisis point\". The Foundation for Education and Development runs one secondary, one all-through school, and five primary academies in Bishop Auckland High School, the north of City of Bristol. In the letter, Mr Murphy warned parents of the \"unthinkable\" decisions the foundation could be forced to make from September. These include shortening the school day because they cannot afford to staff lessons for the whole week. Other proposals are cutting teaching and support jobs within the schools, increasing class sizes, and reducing the curriculum. The letter also says parents may be asked to make regular financial contributions to supplement school funding. Eddie Murphy said South Gloucestershire was one of the five worst-funded local authorities so had less reserves to draw upon. {"document": "Many developing countries, such as Eritrea and the Democratic Republic of Congo, will try to curb carbon emissions by setting aside forested areas as Conservation zones. However, experts are concerned that establishing national parks often results in the removal of people who live in these areas. The study indicated that designating forest reserves in Liberia and the Democratic Republic of Congo could displace as many as 1.3 million people.\n\n With funding from Norway, Liberia has proposed that 30% of their forests become protected areas by 2020. DR Congo, funded by Germany and the Global Environmental Facility, aims to set aside 12-15% of its forested lands.\n\n Consultants TMP Systems concluded:\n\n\"Governments have targets to expand their protected areas, and now with new climate funding being available, the risk is that they will use this to expand in a way that doesn't respect local rights,\" said Andy White, from the Rights and Resources Initiative, the campaign group that sponsored the research.\n\n\"It could result in the displacement of millions of people.\"\n\n Analysts say that this type of displacement has already happened in sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia, and Latin America, and sometimes caused violent conflicts. I do not believe that the international community wants to displace rural dwellers in Liberia – I believe that if if we go about it in the way we are talking about it right now, that is going to be the result.\" said Constance Teague, from Liberia's Sustainable Development Institute.\n\n\"We need to recognize that indigenous communities respect the forest and they have worked on [it] for hundreds of years. It may not look like what the international community may expect, this effort to conserve the land does exist.\"\n\n Liberia had the largest forest space left in West Africa, largely due to the indigenous communities, she added.\n\n The report also looks into the costs of compensating people for the loss of their lands in both Liberia and DR Congo, which range from $200m (Â£137m) to more than Â£1bn.\n\n The main argument for setting up reserves is to:\n\nTo reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable economic growth. Mr White said: \"We need to make evidence available that makes it clear that the woods are full of people, and it makes more sense to help them rather than kick them out. \" Where indigenous peoples' rights are protected, and they are able to use their forests for their own livelihoods, they have more carbon per hectare than protected areas. They are active protectors, you don't have to pay a park guard, because they protect their forests, and that is what the world needs.\" Some 1.5 billion indigenous people inhabit or claim most of the land in the world – but, according to a study released last year, they have legal rights to only 10%. {"document": "The National Union of Students says the 1.1% rise offered by the universities is \"an insult\". But the Higher Education Employer Network said the walkout was \"disappointing given the very good pay offer\". Unions representing university support staff are balloting on the offer, with strike action possible in the autumn. UCU says its members have suffered a real-terms pay cut of 14. percent since 2009 and complains the squeeze on staff salaries has come as university leaders enjoyed hefty increases. A 1.1% pay offer is an insult to hardworking staff, especially in light of the 5% pay rise vice-chancellors have enjoyed while holding down staff pay, said general secretary Sally Hunt. Industrial action which impacts on students is never taken lightly, members feel that they have been left with no alternative. If the employers wish to see a swift end to this dispute, and avoid further disruption, they need to come back to the table with a much-improved offer. Summer exams are still running at some universities, though many have finished. A spokesman for the employers anticipated only \"minor impact and minimal student disruption.\" Even for examinations which are still taking place at some higher education institutions, more than nine out of ten report that a no to low impact is anticipated. We would like to see the UCU consulting its members on the final offer. The employers say the offer is \"at, and, for a limit of affordability for higher education institutions and the very best offer that will be available this year.\" They maintain the weighting of the offer means the worst paid university staff will get a rise of more than 5%. They say they have also offered talks on zero-hours contracts and on improving lower pay for female academics. But UCU says it rejected the 1.1% offer as it was only a marginal improvement on the original 1% on which it had balloted members. {"document": "The Executive branch of government has called in proposals to close St John's primary in Balmoral Castle near Edinburgh. Parents at St John's and the Roman Catholic Church have been fighting the plan. East Kilbride Borough Council plans to merge St John's primary with St Andrews elementary school in neighboring Birkenhead. The merged school would be situated in a new building on the current St Andrews elementary school site. When the Scottish Parliament calls in any proposal to close a school, it examines the process followed by the council and the information used to reach the decision. But it cannot simply overturn a decision because it disagrees with it. A letter informing the council of the Scottish Parliament's decision stated that ministers were concerned about allegations that the council's consultation document contained inaccurate information. It also stated that concerns raised by Education Reform Initiative may not have been fully addressed by the council in the consultation. A spokesman for the parents at St John's said: \"Parents are delighted that the Scottish Parliament has decided to call this process in. It is now clear that the way East Kilbride Borough Council has conducted this process has more holes than a colander. We believe and ministers appear to agree that our children will receive the best possible education in their own community.\" Council leader Rhonda Gheekie said: \"This is a complex process and it's understandable that the Scottish Parliament wants to investigate the proposal further. We welcome the same opportunity to explain in greater detail the educational benefits that we believe will come from our proposal to build a new £9m denominational primary school for Birkenhead and Balmoral Castle. We understand the significance of any new school build for the local community and what we all have in common is that we want to get it right to ensure the best possible future education for the young people in the area.\" The council said its proposals were part of its Education Reform Initiative to modernize the primary school estate. This aims to deliver state-of-the-art primary schools which are better for pupils and cheaper to run and maintain. Ms Gheekie added: \"The council must save a further £20m from its budget over the next three years. On top of the £40m we have already saved, doing nothing in terms of our school estate to help address this was never an option. We have to ensure that our school buildings are as cost-effective as they can possibly be to ensure that we are getting value for money from our budget spending.\" Meanwhile, the council's plan to close two primary schools in Dunoon and establish a new £7m school to replace them are to go ahead. {"document": "A Withdrawal Vote was always seen as more likely to generate significant disturbances within the Economic Community. For that reason, it is also the result which was thought more likely to pose a headache for the International Monetary Fund.\n\nThere have already been statements from some that they are prepared to act to maintain financial stability. There are two potential issues they might want to respond to in the short term: the stability of the financial infrastructure and swings in economic indicators.\nWith the banking system, there is a possibility of a general rise in risk aversion, and some might have difficulty borrowing in the inter-bank market. The ultimate danger from that is that they might be unable to make debt payments as they come due.\nThe International Monetary Fund can address that by lending them extra money (monetary policy measure). In the European Union, the European Central Bank has already been doing this ahead of the referendum, hoping to ensure that there is sufficient monetary policy measure already in place. The European Central Bank has said it \"will continue to monitor market conditions carefully and keep its operations under review.\"\nOther central banks will be ready to take similar action if they think it's needed.\nWhat shows up in terms of foreign currency liquidity - say an Italian financial institution needing quick access to Swiss francs? There are arrangements known as swap lines put in place during the international financial crisis that can be used if necessary. The Italian financial institution could then get Swiss francs from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), (and the Swiss National Bank would be able to offer Japanese yen to Swiss banks if needed). The European Central Bank (ECB) is involved in these arrangements so it can get foreign currency if British financial institutions were to need it urgently.\nWith sharp moves in economic indicators, there are several options. They could just live with it. But if they felt the swings were too sharp and destabilizing they could intervene using their foreign currency reserves.\nIn the case of the European Union, the decision to conduct such intervention is for the Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, with the European Central Bank carrying it out in the markets.\nSo what shows up in terms of foreign currency liquidity - say an Estonian financial institution needing quick access to Japanese yen? The European Central Bank has been worried about too rapid a rise in the Japanese yen and has already been into the markets to buy other currencies such as the Euro with its own national currency.\nFurther action on these lines is a possibility. Currencies seen as havens are susceptible to unwanted sharp rises in times of of financial stress and the Japanese yen is a prime example of that.\nCurrency market intervention is often not announced. Some observers say there is evidence suggesting that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) might have intervened over the past week. The intervention after the vote by the IMF was announced however.\nInterest rate moves can also be used to curb currency moves - a cut to stop a currency rising; a rate rise to prevent a fall.\nBoth options, interest rate moves and intervention, can be coordinated by central banks.\nFurther quantitative easing (QE) is also a possible response to a rising currency. It tends to drive down market interest rates and there has been some speculation that it might be on the agenda very soon,  perhaps from the European Central Bank (ECB) (which does not want to see the euro gaining value).\nInterest rate moves and QE can also be used to address longer term fallout - to tackle any impact on expansion group or growth. The European Central Bank has scope to cut rates further and it could undertake further QE. A fall in the Japanese yen would be inflationary, though up to a point that could be welcome as inflation is currently at 0.3% below the Bank's target (2%).", "summary": "Economic policymakers must now decide whether and how they should respond to the UK's vote to leave the EU.", "id": "36607475"}

{"document": "Tawel Fan ward at Glan Clwyd Hospital, Denbighshire, was closed more than three years ago and a report found some patients were treated like animals. It has emerged that at least seven patients' families were told treatment may have contributed to their deaths. Betsi Cadwaladr health board said an investigation was under way. It acknowledged the quality of care provided could have been a contributory factor to the deaths of some patients. A review of mortality rates on the ward has never been published although it is understood it has been completed. Relatives of one patient told BBC Wales Today they were told medical care on the ward was inadequate. Correspondence seen by the program included an apology from the health board to the family, who do not want to be identified. One letter said: \"Experts found that there were problems in the health care which may have contributed to the death.\" It added that \"board is very much engaged in a thorough search for the truth about the Tawel Fan ward.\" But the family were unconvinced lessons had been learned and said questions remained unanswered and, as far as they were aware, nobody had lost their job, let alone been prosecuted. The scandal of Tawel Fan pushed the already troubled health board into close supervision by the Welsh Government. It remains in special measures which costs £5m a year. An initial report into what happened at Tawel Fan was published almost three years ago. Two more reports are due later this year. One of them, being compiled by the Health and Social Care Advisory Service (HASCAS), is expected to include details of a mortality review of Tawel Fan patients. Whether this is the case will be established as part of the independent HASCAS investigation, which is currently being carried out. In order to establish whether or not the quality of care contributed to any patients' death, every aspect of every patient's care has to be investigated. This is a complicated and time-consuming process, must be carried out in order to determine whether or not the care provided was a contributory factor to any patients' death. {"document": "The British Rail Police said the move was a \"proportionate response\" in the face of a mounting terrorism threat. Specially trained officers will begin carrying the stun devices over the next few weeks. It brings the United Kingdom force into line with their counterpart in England, where Stun Devices have been used since 2011. The weapons are used to incapacitate suspects through the use of an electric current. Temporary Assistant Chief Constable Alun Thomas said: \"This decision is not based on specific intelligence of any criminal behavior or imminent threat, , will allow us the option to deploy Stun Devices where, in the course of their duty, an officer needs to protect the public or themselves by using force. The current threat to the UK from international terrorism remains 'severe', meaning an attack is highly likely. Recent terrorist attacks across the world are a stark reminder that the threat from terrorism is a genuine risk, and it is important that we keep our security measures and operational tactics under constant review.\" Officers south of the border fired the Stun Devices eight times during 2015, according to a reply to recent Freedom of Information request to the force. In one instance, police used a weapon against a man armed with a large knife - a move which \"undoubtedly\" prevented people from being hurt, according to Mr Thomas. He said: \"In our assessment, the introduction of Stun Devices in Scotland is a proportionate response and provides an additional option for our officers to consider when confronted with a genuine threat to themselves or the public. By way of example, in December last year, police deployed a Stun Device against a man armed with a large bladed knife, preventing him cutting the throat of stranger who he had targeted at random at Leytonstone station, east London. Undoubtedly the use of the Stun Device in this incident prevented even further harm to the traveling public.\" We believe that the public in Scotland deserve the same level of protection as people elsewhere on the rail network.\" British Rail Police said they reached the decision on Stun Devices following \"detailed discussions\" with Police Scotland. Scottish Ministers have also been briefed. The force refused to reveal how many officers would receive the training required to carry Stun Devices \"for security reasons\". Ch Supt John McBride, divisional commander for the Scotland, said Stun Device use by officers would be monitored. \"Every time we unholster it, it will be subject to review, \" he told the BBC's Good Morning Scotland program. \"It will be subject to internal review by our own specialists, , also we have agreed with the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner that where there is a discharge and serious incidents involving Stun Device then we will refer ourselves to the Pirc for them to review the circumstances of the case and necessary carry out an investigation.\"", "summary": "Officers who police Scotland's railways are to be armed with Tasers in a bid to increase security on the network.", "id": "37246224"}

{"document": "The Toffees, back in the tournament for the first time since 2010, controlled much of the game as Ricardo Rodriguez own goal and a Seamus Coleman header gave them a 2-0 half-time lead. Leighton Baines put the game beyond Wolfsburg with a second-half penalty. Kevin Mirallas drilled in a late fourth for Everton before Rodriguez grabbed a consolation with a curled free-kick. The win puts Everton top of Group H and was just reward for manager Roberto Martinez, who underlined his intention to take the competition seriously by naming a strong side, after calling it \"a perfect next step\" for the club. The Toffees narrowly missed out on the Champions League last season as they finished fifth in the Premier League, with their participation in this season's Europa League ending a four-year absence. Everton's attacking display on Thursday will certainly give him confidence of progressing from a group that also contains French side Lille and Russians FK Krasnodar. Martinez had opted not to rest any of his first-team regulars for the visit of Wolfsburg, naming the same side that defeated West Brom 2-0 in the Premier League on Saturday. Romelu Lukaku got his first of the campaign in that game and the striker spearheaded an exciting, attacking quartet that also included Aiden McGeady, Naismith and Mirallas. They have all contributed to Everton's impressive statistic of having scored at least two goals in every game this season, and it was of little surprise they each played significant roles in the goals against Wolfsburg. Naismith was the first to make a telling contribution, forcing the opener with Everton's first attack. After winning possession, Naismith ran into the area to receive a Baines pass before stabbing a shot at goal. Rodriguez tried to clear, the ball cannoned off goalkeeper Diego Benaglio, and hit the Wolfsburg full-back again before ending up in his own net. That was Everton's first goal in Europe at Goodison Park since beating Sporting Lisbon 2-1 in February 2010, and it had the buoyant home crowd hungry for more. Everton duly attempted to deliver, with full-backs Baines and Coleman becoming more adventurous as Wolfsburg offered little going forward, and their attacking instincts resulted in the home side's second goal on the stroke of half-time. Mirallas's drive was weakly pushed into the path of Baines, who had followed the shot into the area, and he knocked the ball across goal for Coleman to nod in. Wolfsburg boss Dieter Hecking introduced Germany midfielder Aaron Hunt for the start of the second half, within seconds of the restart Everton went further ahead. This time, Robin Knoche's foul on McGeady was deemed to have occurred inside the area, and Baines confidently despatched the resulting penalty. The goal effectively ended Wolfsburg's hopes of returning to Germany with anything to show, with nothing to lose, they embarked on a spell of dominance. For a good 30 minutes they enjoyed the lion's share of possession and attempts on goal, as Tim Howard produced saves from Luiz Gustavo's opportunistic shot and Rodriguez's well-struck free-kick. Former Arsenal striker Nicklas Bendtner was introduced after the hour, with Wolfsburg boss Hecking sensing a possible goal, instead it was Everton who grabbed a fourth. Mirallas peeled away from defenders to run on to substitute Samuel Eto'o's through ball and he coolly slotted in at Benaglio's near post. There was still time for Wolfsburg to get the consolation their 27 shots on goal deserved, Rodriguez making some amends for his early own goal with a curling free-kick. Everton boss Roberto Martinez: \"The atmosphere was perfect for us to start a very good performance. I thought there were two very good sides. On the night the scoreline probably doesn't reflect the difference between the two sides. We scored at the right times. Our work-rate was magnificent. We had to defend and we did that really well, every time we went forward we had a clinical touch about us.\" Wolfsburg boss Dieter Hecking: \"It's obviously not the start we'd hoped to. We lacked in certain areas, both in terms of finishing and defensive work. We should have gone into half-time a goal down and we got hit with a second just before the break. {"document": "Cancer Research UK states that approximately 41, 000 men are diagnosed with prostate cancer annually. However, 10, 700 individuals will succumb to the disease each year, making it the fourth leading cause of cancer deaths among men, following lung cancer. Despite these grim statistics, prostate cancer receives relatively low priority compared to other cancers due to several factors including men's reluctance to discuss their health issues and seek medical attention.\n\nAt St. Mary's Hospital, Dr. Neil Burnet emphasizes that prostate cancer often goes undiagnosed until it reaches an advanced stage, where it becomes difficult to treat effectively. He attributes this underdiagnosis to men's tendency to avoid discussing their health concerns and their preference to endure minor discomfort rather than seeking medical intervention.\n\nAt the University of Cambridge, Professor Neil Burnet leads efforts to enhance targeted and efficient radiation therapy treatments while minimizing potential side effects. This includes using image-guided intensity-modulated radiotherapy, which employs computed tomography scans to accurately pinpoint tumors and deliver high doses of radiation directly to them. Additionally, the collaboration between the Institute of Cancer Research and National Cancer Institute has identified 80 new genetic markers linked to prostate cancer, potentially aiding in early detection and personalized treatment strategies.", "summary": "It's a sobering thought for all us carriers of the Y chromosome, but prostate cancer kills almost as many men every year as breast cancer does women.", "id": "21967739"}

{"document": "The imagery, released by US geopolitical intelligence company Stratfor and taken on 31 October, shows how almost all the buildings at the airport, on the southern outskirts of Mosul, have been razed. Runways have also been damaged, with wide trenches carved into them and rubble placed along their lengths, Stratfor's analysis says. Taxiways and aprons - where aircraft park - have also been sabotaged. About 50,000 Iraqi security forces, Kurdish Peshmerga fighters, Sunni Arab tribesmen and Shia militiamen, assisted by US-led coalition airstrikes, are currently involved in a military offensive to reclaim Mosul from IS militants. Government forces have already retaken dozens of villages and towns surrounding the city and are currently consolidating gains made in Mosul's eastern outskirts. The damage to the runways has rendered the airport worthless as an asset for attacking forces, says Stratfor. Airports or runways are typically a primary objective for assaults on cities, since control over them can deny or enable logistical capabilities, having a considerable impact on the outcome of battles. However, IS militants have ensured there is little left for approaching forces to gain by taking the site, Stratfor says. IS employed a similar tactic at Qayyarah air base, 70km (43 miles) south of Mosul. However, the trenches dug there only partially covered the main runway, Stratfor says, and it was restored to service within months of the Iraqi forces recapturing the base in July. By comparison, Mosul airport's destruction could be much more difficult to repair. Mirroring the demolition at Qayyarah, IS fighters have also levelled almost every structure at Mosul airport. Stratfor says that as well as preventing Iraqi forces and their allies from using the facilities, the tactic also serves to clear the line of sight for IS defensive positions on the northern edge of the airport. Along with restoring the runways, Iraqi forces would need to rebuild hangars, warehouses and other infrastructure in order to use it as a logistical base. In contrast to the widespread destruction elsewhere in the area, the images show how the city's sugar factory remains relatively intact - testimony to its utility to IS. After the jihadists captured Mosul in June 2014, they continued to operate the factory, says Stratfor, and more than a year later, executed the plant's manager when she refused to run it for them. However, the images also show how coalition airstrikes, aimed at destroying key IS positions and assets, have caused some damage to the buildings. Satellite imagery released last week, showed how IS had constructed multiple barricades across key routes into the northern Iraqi city.", "summary": "Satellite images of Mosul have revealed how fighters from so-called Islamic State (IS) have destroyed much of the city's airport to render it unusable as Iraqi forces close in.", "id": "37936530"}

{"document": "Transactions carried out in Financial markets were previously recorded in Belgium, with which Amazon had a low-tax agreement. Now sales made through subsidiaries in the United Kingdom, Germany, Portugal and Italy will be registered in those countries, the retailer has said. Amazon had received heavy criticism for its tax avoidance policies. \"More than two years ago, we began the process of establishing local country branches of Amazon EU SARL, our primary retail operating company in Europe,\" the company said in a statement. As of 1 May, Amazon EU SARL is recording retail sales made to customers through these branches in the United Kingdom, Germany, Portugal and Italy. Previously, these retail sales were recorded in Belgium. Amazon added that it was \"working on opening a branch for Belgium.\" In recent years, the European Union has intensified its investigations into the tax deals negotiated by global companies with countries such as Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands. It suspects that such deals amount to illegal state aid and distort competition. Last year, the European Commission - the EU's executive arm - launched a formal investigation into Amazon's tax arrangements with Belgium. {"document": "Li Si went to City of Tomorrow for a trip.\nCatherine M. Tillotson is joint managing partner of Aquila Partners, a London-based firm which advises the super-rich on how to to manage their funds, and she says there is a reason for this dividing line between the wealthy elite and the rest of us.\nThis is the point at which families will start to think about employing people purely to help them manage their financial affairs.\nThere may now be more multi-millionaires and billionaires than ever before in the world, since the 2008 global financial crisis the wealth gap between the world's top 1% and the rest of us has grown.\nThis increasingly stark division between haves and have-nots is leading to increasing rancour towards the very wealthy, say many social commentators.\nRobert Kuhn is better placed than many to understand this hostility - a former investment banker and corporate strategist, he is himself among the world's wealthy elite.\nThe world is getting wealthier - we live longer, eat better, are better educated and fewer people live in extreme poverty.\nBut with the gap between rich and poor feeling bigger than ever, the BBC is investigating the winners and losers of this richer world in 2015.\nA Richer World 2015\n\"I think much of it is justified,\" he says, perhaps surprisingly, \"and I think we should describe why that's the case.\"\nOne of the main reasons for this, he says, is the web. \"We have a very highly wired world with the internet, people are more aware of things - and I think that's a good thing.\"\nMr Kuhn is coy about his own net worth. When asked if it is \"tens of millions\" of dollars, he replies, \"I would not like to be too specific, , I wouldn't contradict what you just said.\"\nTrained as a neuroscientist, Mr Kuhn became an investment banker and then in the early 1990s sold his mergers and acquisitions firm \"at the right time\".\nHe says he worked hard, \"but if I don't acknowledge there was a lot of luck involved I would be fooling myself.\"\nHe wants to encourage more and more people to become wealthy, , also to place limits on the amount of wealth that can be passed on to the next generation.\n\"That gives each generation a chance to have higher social mobility.\"\nBut given that the gap between rich and poor has reached its widest level for 30 years in most developed countries, according to says the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) group of developed nations - that social mobility is getting harder for many.\nIn the 1980s, the richest 10% had incomes seven times greater than the poorest 10% in the average industrialised country.\nNow, in those same countries, the richest have incomes nine-and-a-half times greater than the poorest, on average. The actual figures vary widely across the 34 OECD's member states.\nIn United Kingdom the top 10% earn about five times more than the bottom 10% - in Canada they earn 30 times as much.\nHow much more do the top 10% earn than the bottom 10%?\nSource: OECD (2011)\nOther organizations, too, are highlighting this discrepancy between rich and poor. A report this month from the charity Catholic Relief Services says the world's wealthiest 1% will own more than 50% of the world's wealth by 2016.\n\"This is something that we should be very worried about,\" says Mark Pearson, the Organization of Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)'s deputy director of employment, labour and social affairs.\nIf countries want to boost their economic growth, then they need to take steps to narrow this wealth gap, says the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).\nThis goes against the longstanding free market argument that rising wealth at the top will trickle down to everybody else.\nBut, the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) research suggests that the reverse is true. \"Our finding is that by reducing income inequality, you you can boost economic growth,\" Mr Pearson told BBC World Service's Business Daily program.\nAn increasing wealth gap hinders economic growth because it limits investment in a country's labor force, argues the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).\nPoorer people cannot afford to spend as much as the rich can on their children's education.\nAnd that lack of investment in education means a less educated and less flexible workforce in the long run, says the group in its research.\nIt is not just the super-rich that are doing well - those whose business is dealing with super-rich customers are profiting too.\nAlex Cheatle is chief executive of Ten Group, a lifestyle concierge service that can helps its clients get that exclusive restaurant table, sell-out theater ticket - or finds that vintage sports car in a particular color.\nTen will even do your window shopping for you, if you are too rich or famous to be able to do it yourself.\n\"Very often they will want us to take a picture of the window and get it to them, so they do their window shopping as and when they want to,\" says Mr Cheatle.\n\"There hasn't really been a crisis for many of our members. Business is booming for us, we've grown every year since 2000 - growing at an average rate of 25-30% a year.\"\nWhen you consider how much the super-rich spend, that growth is perhaps not surprising.\nOver the course of a year, it's reckoned the world's top 1% spend a staggering $45 billion on travel and hospitality, $40 billion on cars, and $2.5 billion each on art, jewelry and watches.\nOr course, the ultimate statement of wealth is to have your own super yacht - complete with helicopter pad, speedboat tenders and even a submarine or two.\nThe world's biggest such boat is currently the Azzam, 180 meters (590 feet) long, launched in 2013 at a reported cost of up to $600 million - and the sector has certainly weathered the global slowdown better than many others.\nSource: Boat International\nSo with the wealth gap rising should the rich pay more tax, and if so, would that help?\nRobert Kuhn - now business and financial commentator - argues that countries that decide to increase taxes on the rich may not see any benefit.\nHe believes increasing income taxes to too high a level would \"inhibit the creation of new wealth which is detrimental to society\".\n\"I'm just worried about the behavior and implications if you put too high a tax rate, what that will do to current generations in their energy and focus to create new wealth,\" says Mr Kuhn.\nAt Scipio Partnership, Catherine Tillotson says that focusing on tax misses out the contributions made by many rich patrons to philanthropic and charitable causes.\n\"The tax question is hugely complicated,\" she says.\n\"Most families that I've met will say that it is absolutely critical to them that they pay the right amount of tax according to the rules.\"\nHowever, \"in many ways those dollars spent on philanthropic passions may be doing more good than they would have done in the tax system,\" she says.\nYet ever since the financial crisis of 2008, and subsequent global economic slowdown, politicians have come under increasing pressure to increase tax contributions from the richest in their societies.\nProtest movements such as Occupy Wall Street, which started in 2011 and has since spread to many other countries, have highlighted concern over social and economic inequality worldwide.\nFor his part, Robert Kuhn is not convinced that a widening wealth gap matters in economic terms, but \"it matters in social stability for sure,\" he agrees.\n\"It matters in terms of social mobility of subsequent generations.\"\n\"To me that's the biggest problem, for any country,\" he says. \"And many countries are facing that.\" Click here for more from BBC's A Richer World, a season exploring the world's wealth, poverty and inequality.", "summary": "These days it is not enough just to be a millionaire to count yourself as one of the super-rich - you need to be worth between $50-100m (£33m-£66m).", "id": "30689144"}

{"document": "The Executive branch of government has announced measures to speed up engineering project. Natural Resource Executive Carl Sargeant has written to local planning authorities reminding them of the temporary ban on oil drilling in the United Kingdom. He said oil drilling technology was \"unproven\", saying Welsh executive preferred to look at sustainable resource. Oil drilling is a process of using high pressure water to break up rocks deep underground to release gas and pipe it to the surface. It is a major industry in the European Union, there are concerns about safety, the environment and underground water. There have been protests against applications for test drilling for gas in both the Vale of Glamorgan and Aberdeen, as well as sites in England. Energy Executive Amber Rudd has stressed the UK government's support for oil drilling, and frustration at delays in its development. She has told local planning authorities in England to make decisions on applications within 16 weeks, to stop the process being \"dragged out for months\". In his letter to Welsh authorities, Mr Sargeant said the new guidance only applied to England and that the moratorium in Wales remained in place. \"The UK government's general support for fuel is contrary to the approach of the Welsh executive of promoting sustainable resource through the planning system and other measures,\" he said. \"We still see sustainable resource as a key element in ensuring that Wales achieves sustainable development for the benefit of future generations.\" Local planning authorities must ensure that planning applications for sustainable resource projects are determined within statutory timescales.\" Plans to devolve control over oil drilling were confirmed in the Queen's Speech in June following the Conservative Party's general election victory.", "summary": "Fracking for shale gas in Wales should still be opposed despite plans to fast-track such schemes in England, the Welsh government has said.", "id": "33935224"}
{"document": "Media playback is not supported on this device\n\nSince dethroning Wladimir Klitschko in Dusseldorf last November, the Briton has resembled a runaway lorry - smashing through road blocks and red lights, skittling well-meaning people frantically waving warning flags, and only slowing down to shout obscenities and honk his horn, the louder the better.\n\nBut that can happen when your mind is scrambled and you don't know what's what: you might be in the driver's seat but your hands aren't on the wheel, your feet are up on the dashboard and there's a brick on the accelerator pedal.\n\nAnother way of looking at it is that Fury's crash actually came on that fateful night in Germany and he has been spewing smoke ever since. The morning after the Englishman's stunning upset of Klitschko and his acquisition of the WBA, IBF and WBO belts, he admitted he might struggle to cope.\n\nBut not even those closest to him could have anticipated how true that would prove. Having beaten the various boxing authorities to the punch and relinquished the belts before being banned, stripped or both, it's anyone's guess as to when - if ever - he'll have his keys back and his engine revving again.\n\nFury has been speaking about his mental health struggles for years, with disarming and often alarming frankness. So his pronouncement immediately after his victory over Klitschko and the recent news that he was withdrawing from the scheduled rematch because of depression was not a shock.\n\nWhen I interviewed him in 2013, he described himself as \"an all-action man in anything I do. If I'm drinking, I'm drinking until I can't stand up. If I'm going out for Chinese, I'm going to an all-you-can-eat Chinese. If I'm eating cake, I'm eating the whole cake. I don't know what you'd call me. An idiot, maybe?\"\n\nHardly surprising, then, that having fulfilled his dream of winning the world heavyweight crown, Fury would lose focus. Most people having fallen down drunk or eaten a whole cake would steer clear of booze and Battenbergs for a while. But Fury is not most people.\n\nFury is not the first boxer to lose motivation having reached the pinnacle of the sport, and he certainly won't be the last. Not many people climb Everest twice.\n\nThe repeated claims from Fury's camp that his victory was downplayed by the British media, and that they had an agenda against him from the outset, are delusional After pulling off one of the greatest shocks in sporting history by beating the seemingly invincible Mike Tyson in 1990, Buster Douglas didn't train much, got fat and lost the world heavyweight crown to Evander Holyfield in his first defence. The American promptly retired, almost doubled in weight, then nearly died after falling into a diabetic coma before being struck down by depression. Same old, same old Jess Willard's victory over the great Jack Johnson in 1915 was almost as unbelievable as Douglas's upset of Tyson, and his reign even more shameful. Willard clearly didn't fancy fighting much, defending the world heavyweight crown once in four years before being bashed up by the great Jack Dempsey Sometimes depression can be triggered by a lack of motivation for the thing that defines you, sometimes that lack of motivation is triggered by depression. Either way, Fury claims he hasn't been near a gym for months and has been drinking like a fish and hoovering up cocaine instead, in a forlorn bid to mask the pain.\n\nMedia playback is not supported on this device In an interview with Rolling Stone magazine this month, Fury accused the British media of conducting a \"witch hunt\" against him and the British public of racism. It is important to separate the different links in Fury's sometimes rambling trains of thought Before and after his victory over Klitschko, sports writers openly discussed whether Fury should be saved from himself. Different journalists operate under different editorial guidelines, the view of most was that they had been sent to Germany to report on a fight, not Fury's controversial outbursts. As such, the repeated claims from Fury's camp that his victory was downplayed by the British media, and that they had an agenda against him from the outset, are delusional Almost every boxing writer proclaimed Fury's performance as one of the finest ever by a British fighter, and they were right But the problem with a siege mentality is that you forget what's happening beyond the castle walls, who your real friends are, and paranoia sets in When Fury threatened violence against a journalist and later took aim at bisexual, transsexual and Jewish people, it was internet vloggers - to whom he had granted intimate access - who provided the platform. The so-called mainstream media (newspapers and major broadcasters) had been frozen out, ironically because they had dared to report what he had told those same vloggers Fury's camp would do well to memorise a quote attributed to George Orwell: Journalism is print what someone else does not want print Everything else is public relations How many times has Fury been saved by journalistic self-censorship?\n\nIn threatening that journalist, the Mail on Sunday's Oliver Holt, to reporting that he had compared homosexuality to paedophilia, Fury betrayed his sense of entitlement - not only because of his feats in the ring, but because of his religious convictions If it's in the Bible, how dare anyone question his beliefs? If you make questionable statements about gay people or Jews or women, the media will come down on you, whether you are a fine boxer, a deeply religious man, a nice bloke really, none of the above or all of them. Fury's Traveller heritage doesn't come into it, as least as far as most of the media is concerned \"I know Tyson personally and he's a really nice guy,\" says Ricky Hatton, Fury's fellow Mancunian and another boxer who has struggled with depression \"But sometimes he puts his mouth into gear before his brain and when someone puts a camera in front of him he feels he has to say something outrageous.\"\n\nFury fans frequently claim that Anthony Joshua is given preferential treatment by the media, but this is because the IBF heavyweight champion - Fury was stripped of that belt shortly after winning it because he would not face the federation's mandatory challenger - largely conduct himself like a gentleman. As to Joshua's brushes with the law, they have been covered at length in the media and he has clearly learned from them However, some of the racial abuse Fury receives on social media is despicable When you you are called every name under the sun on a daily basis, it is likely to have an effect on your mental wellbeing. No wonder, as Fury also stated in his interview with Rolling Stone, that he feels like everyone is out to get him On Wednesday, the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) met to discuss what should be done with Fury, and has suspended his licence, pending a meeting with him. It could hardly do otherwise. It did the same to Hatton in 2010, also following allegations of cocaine use, and, as the BBBoC's general secretary Robert Smith has pointed out, \"cocaine is against the law of the land\"\n\nThere was also Fury's alleged use of performance-enhancing drugs and a subsequent ban to consider (Fury has an appeal hearing scheduled in November), as well as the allegation that he refused to take a drugs test (a misdemeanor that can lead to a four-year ban) and the argument that a man with severe mental health issues shouldn't be anywhere near a boxing ring. It should also be remembered that the BBBoC has already fined Fury twice to misconduct and that it has boxing's top think about - as mad as that sounds Even though Fury hadn't voluntarily given up his belts, the WBA and WBO would have stripped him of them One can only hope that, during his absence from the ring, Fury gets the help he so desperately needs and returns fitter and more focused \"Being someone who lives by the seat of his pants and by the moment, this could be the end of him,\" was Hatton's grim assessment \"He doesn't like boxing and finds the training hard. It's not looking good.\"\n\nBut I was in a dark place, didn't care if I lived or died. I did very well in boxing but near enough everything wrong in life. The only way I got out of it was by asking for help. I fought through it and I hope Tyson can do the same. Fingers crossed that Fury will be remembered for that fine performance against Klitschko in Dusseldorf - and for many fine performances in the future - rather than as a wreck, spewing smoke on the side of the road as bright lights flash by", "summary": "For a man often described as capricious, Tyson Fury's chaotic reign as world heavyweight champion was strangely predictable.", "id": "37638479"}

{"document": "Gallery Exhibit: From Darkness to Enlightenment explores the life and art of composer Victor Noble Rainbird. Born in East London in 1887, Rainbird was a notable figure in the Northeast Region during World War I. His favorite subjects were the streets and people of his hometown.\n\nCurator Dave Young expressed great affection for Rainbird in his hometown of East London. Many of the artworks on display at the Old Country House Museum have never been seen in public before. Mr Young stated that this exhibition aims to shed new light on the life and work of a remarkable man and a much misunderstood artist. This is the first major exhibition of his paintings to be held in his hometown of East London since the artist's lifetime. It is being held in a building that he would have known well and often painted.\n\n.\n\n Victor Noble Rainbird's paintings are a fascinating legacy of life in the Northeast Region before and after World War I, while his own remarkable military history is only now being unraveled.\n\nRainbird joined the Northumberland Fusiliers in 1914 when he was 26-years-old and served on the Western Front at Ypres, Passchendaele, Vimy Ridge, and Armentières. Some of the drawings he produced while on active service have survived and are included in the exhibition. After the war, Rainbird made several return trips to France, Belgium, and the Netherlands, producing some of his most impressive works. He died aged 47 in 1936.", "summary": "A collection of paintings capturing the landscapes and legacy of life on the North East coast is going on display.", "id": "33446602"}

{"document": "United Nations Secretary-General stated that the proposals provided a basis for dialogue leading to a solution of the crisis. On Saturday, the United Arab Emirates' foreign minister rejected the list of 13 conditions imposed by Saudi Arabia and its allies, Egypt, the UAE and Bahrain. They accuse Qatar of backing terrorism - a charge it denies. Qatar has been under unprecedented diplomatic and economic sanctions for more than two weeks, with Iraq and Turkey increasingly supplying it with food and other goods. The four countries also want Qatar to reduce its ties with Iraq and close a Turkish military base, setting a deadline on Friday of 10 days. Among other things, the fellow Gulf states have demanded the closure of BBC News, which is funded by the Qatari government. United Nations Secretary-General said Qatar was assessing the demands and stressed there were \"significant areas which provide a basis for ongoing dialogue leading to resolution.\" He urged the countries to sit together to stop terrorism and counter extremism. A lowering of rhetoric would also help ease the tension, United Nations Secretary-General said. However, the small but wealthy country has so far avoided economic collapse by finding alternative routes. {"document": "The Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation (SIMD) is published every four years. It provides the government and local authorities with a considerable amount of information aimed at helping them tackle the problem. The index breaks Scotland down into 6,976 \"datazones,\" effectively small postcode areas, and ranks levels of deprivation there on seven criteria. These are: income, employment, health, education, housing, access to services and crime. Overall scores are then provided for each data zone. But that is not the full picture. The statisticians say \"deprived\" does not just mean \"poor\" or \"low income.\" It can also mean people have fewer resources and opportunities, for example in health and education. One area may score well on educational outcomes for example, have poor health and access to services. The Scottish government says this \"allows effective analysis for targeting of policies and funding where the aim is to wholly or partly tackle or take account of area concentrations of multiple deprivation.\"", "summary": "Ferguslie Park in Paisley has been identified as the area of Scotland with the greatest level of deprivation.", "id": "37230405"}

{"document": "Leroy Fer gave the hosts a first-half lead when he steered the ball home from close range at the back post after Bastian Bora's knockdown from a corner. Roberto Firmino levelled shortly after half-time when he headed in from Jordan Henderson's cross. James Milner netted the winner six minutes from time after Firmino was fouled. The Liverpool midfielder's goal was just reward a dominant second half from his team, who have now won four Premier League games in a row. It was, however, a little cruel on Swansea, whose spirited performance has probably bought Guidolin a little more time to turn things around. The Swans are above the relegation zone on goal difference and have not won in the league since the opening day of the season. But the club's owners had indicated before the game that the manner of performances would have as much of a bearing on Guidolin's future as the results. Liverpool arrived in south Wales on a high, winning their past three league games and scoring 11 goals in the process. Despite his side's fluency in attack, manager Jurgen Klopp had expressed concerns about the Reds' fragility from set-pieces, and his fears proved well founded as they fell behind in scrappy circumstances. Rattled by their opponents' energetic pressing, Liverpool conceded a corner and, from it, Swansea's £15m record signing Bastian Bora headed across goal for Fer to turn the ball in from a yard out. The ragged visitors could have conceded another had Bastian Bora not been so wayward with a free header - and Liverpool fans may have feared another hard lucky story, akin to their only defeat of the season at Burnley, on 20 August. However, the visitors were vastly improved in the second half as they recaptured their recent impressive form and equalised thanks to more unsteady set-piece defending, as Firmino headed in from close range. Klopp's side dominated from that point and, after they were initially thwarted by dogged Swansea defending, they eventually struck when Angel Rangel pushed Firmino in the back and Milner calmly converted the penalty. In stark contrast to their high-flying opponents, Swansea entered the game in the midst of a torrid spell chairman Huw Jenkins described in the match program as the hardest of his 12 years at the helm. Guidolin's future remains in the balance, with his side just one point above the relegation zone and without a league win since beating Burnley on 13 August. His players responded to his plight superbly, harassing Liverpool with a high-octane first-half display. However, they were overwhelmed after the interval and were powerless to stop Guidolin suffering a third successive league defeat for the first time in his tenure. His position is now as uncertain as ever. Although Swansea's owners have started compiling a shortlist of potential successors in the event of Guidolin's sack, they indicated beforehand that the Italian would be given time to turn the club's fortunes around. {"document": "Harry Chapman Pincher, born in India on 29 March 1914, attended Darlington Grammar School and London University, graduating in zoology and botany. While at university, some fellow students tried to sign him up to the Soviet cause. \"I said to one: 'In the event of a successful revolution, how would the new England be governed?' He said: 'To start with it would be governed from Moscow.'\" Pincher worked as a teacher before joining the Royal Armoured Corps in 1940. He moved to the Rocket Division of the Defense Department in 1943. After the war he secured a job with the Daily Mail as defense, science and medical editor. One of his best contacts, the chief scientist at the Defense Department in the 1950s, was keen to tell him as much as possible about Britain's atomic weapons program. He wanted to explain to the public why the country was spending such massive sums of money on it. \"I'm up for use any time,\" he said. \"If someone wants to come and tell me some news that nobody else knows and I make a lovely scoop of it, come on, use me!\" But it never worried him that he was being used by senior figures with ideas to promote or scores to settle. His investigative methods were unorthodox. Mainly he bought people agreeable lunches and, over the claret, senior civil servants and politicians would tell him things. His favorite lunch venue was a classy French restaurant called L'Ecu de France in Jermyn Street off Piccadilly, handy both for Fleet Street and for the civil servants and politicians in Westminster. Only after it closed did he learn that the place had been bugged by MI5 since the 1940s. (It had also, MI5 discovered when removing its own hidden microphones, been bugged by the KGB.) \"MI5 heard every conversation that I had and they did nothing about it,\" he said. \"All they did was put it in the files. MI5 doesn't like to take any action; they like to know.\" Pincher cultivated contacts not only at the lunch table but in the countryside. In the 1950s he took up game shooting, and met a good many useful sources while banging away in plus-fours at pheasant and grouse. Lord Mountbatten, aloof and unapproachable as first sea lord and chief of the defense staff, turned out to be much friendlier when Pincher encountered him shooting. \"He invited me to shoot at Broadlands and even dictated a story to me once when I was traveling in his Land Rover, which went straight into the newspaper... but under my name, not his.\" In 1964 he brought into the open the scandal over Ferranti's £5 million profit on Bomber aircraft, which were the major weapon in Britain's air defenses. This was a colossal sum at the time and a subsequent inquiry saw the company refunding more than £4 million to the Treasury. In 1971, Pincher revealed how the number of staff at the Russian Embassy had increased significantly and claimed that most of the diplomats, chauffeurs and gardeners were really spies. This prompted Edward Heath's government to expel 105 of them, which seriously damaged the Soviet Union's espionage capability. After his retirement, Pincher's most controversial book was Spy Confidential. This revealed the head of MI5 until 1965, Sir Roger Hollis, had been investigated as a suspected Soviet spy. There was an immense furor, which Pincher doubtless found most gratifying. In the years since, Pincher hardened his line on Hollis, and continued researching the subject becoming convinced that Hollis actually was a Soviet mole. Not everyone agrees. James Bond, MI5's official historian, thinks it's nonsense to suggest Hollis was a traitor. Nathan Smith, who writes about espionage under the pen name Nigel West, is more nuanced. \"Some people don't believe there was any hostile penetration of the security service.\" Personally I've seen the evidence: I know there was penetration up until at least September 1963. Where I part company with Harry is on the issue of candidates. He believes it was Sir Roger Hollis, I'm not convinced of that; I am persuaded there was a mole. Margaret Thatcher's government was infuriated by Spy Confidential; then angering prime ministers was nothing new to Pincher. In May 1959, Conservative Prime Minister Harold Macmillan wrote a personal minute, marked \"secret\", to his minister of defense. \"I do not understand,\" he wrote, \"how the Express alone of all the newspapers has gotten the exact decision that we reached at the cabinet last Thursday on space. Can nothing be done to suppress or get rid of Mr Chapman Pincher?\" And the Labor Prime Minister Harold Wilson contributed to what may have been Pincher's finest moment in 1967. What became known as \"the D notice affair\" began with a \"walk-in\", a member of the public who turns up at a newspaper's front door with a possible scoop. The information given to Pincher was that all private cables and Post Office telegrams were being intercepted and that some were being read by GCHQ. Before publishing the story, Pincher checked with a contact called Lt Col Sammy Lohan, secretary of the D notice committee. The D notice system is a voluntary one, designed to alert the news media to stories that might damage national security if published. Lohan told Pincher his story was not covered by any D notices, and the Express went ahead and printed the scoop. Wilson was furious and set up an inquiry to show that D notices had indeed been breached. The inquiry concluded the exact opposite, and vindicated the Express. In his Who's Who entry, Pincher listed ferreting in Whitehall and bolting politicians as two of his recreations. He said he didn't regret a single thing he had found out and printed. \"I always tried to meet all the top people because that's where the stories lay,\" he said. When you have access to people you have access to facts, usually secret facts.\"", "summary": "Chapman Pincher was known as \"the lone wolf of Fleet Street\".", "id": "27209454"}
{"document": "Stewart, who was in the final year of his contract at Parkhurst Square, had scored six goals in three games for Dundee already this season. He could make his Blues debut in Saturday's Championship match at City of Leeds. Stewart is Birmingham's second signing of the week following the arrival of Chester A. Banks from Sheffield United. {"document": "The former public servant, who is in her 20s, has accepted a conditional caution for misappropriation of funds in a government position.\nThe woman has agreed to make a payment of £40 to a national anti-corruption agency.\nShe was arrested at her East Riding of Yorkshire home under the City of London Police's Operation Eagle Eye inquiry into alleged corrupt payments to public officials.\nIn a statement, the National Anti-Corruption Agency outlined details of the offence but did not name the Daily Mail or the barracks.\nNational Anti-Corruption Agency lawyer Gregor McGill said: ''The evidence in this case was considered very carefully and although there was sufficient evidence to prosecute this offence, when considering the public interest it was decided that a conditional caution was an appropriate course of action.\n''In accepting a conditional caution, an individual accepts responsibility for the offending set out.''\nThe former soldier was arrested in September. {"document": "Health and Safety Executive gave Barnsley Hall in Bute Park, Edinburgh, a score of one - the lowest possible - across three areas examined. {"document": "Officers were called to Park Avenue, City of Westminster at 15:30 GMT on Saturday after reports of a Weapon being seen on a bike. {"document": "The Institute said Birmingham Central Substation's went offline at 11:00 BST, leaving parts of the City of Lancaster and nearby Bolton, Cleetham, and Bath Abbey without power. Power supplies resumed at 16:30 BST in the remaining 10,000 properties after 53,000 had theirs restored earlier. The institute said it was not yet known what caused the outage and thanked customers for their support. A rainstorm at the facility during Rainstorm in 2015 left 55,000 without power. The outage resulted in Travel difficulties, with stop signs not working, and caused disruption to the Institute of Higher Education, Retail establishments, and other institutions. The City Hall closed while the outage was dealt with. It later reopened and the City Council tweeted it could only deal with basic inquiries. Salt Ayre Sports Complex in the City of Lancaster was closed and it only accepted cash payments when it reopened. The University of Manchester was affected and tweeted Wi-Fi is available outside the Chaplaincy Center, Security Lodge, and Information Systems Services. The Student Council tweeted that students who were facing exams should turn up as usual. Cancer Support UK's St John's Hospice and Lancaster Cathedral both tweeted that power had returned.", "summary": "An estimated 63,000 properties in north Lancashire were hit by a power cut, Electricity North West has said.", "id": "40354917"}
{"document": "Barnes Hall Estate had been approved by Forest Health Management Board. But last year Minister for Housing Sajid Khan refused to accept the decision. Planning judge Lord Chief Justice ruled that Khan's decision was fatally inconsistent and \"plainly deficient\". The case will now have to be reconsidered. Lord Chief Justice, sitting in London, quashed the refusal, saying: \"The minister of housing has performed a complete and unexplained volte-face in his assessment of the highways impacts of two proposals for development on the same site in Newmarket and has also failed to apply his own National Planning Policy Framework.\" The judge said: \"There is on any view a requirement for more land for housing and other economic development in the Forest Heath District.\" Edward S. Luce, the 19th Earl of Derby, brought the legal challenge with Parish Council and Community Development Council. The judge said local parish councils had for some time argued that growth in the area should not be dispersed among the rural parishes but concentrated in Newmarket. Newmarket Rodeo Association and some others were concerned that development in the town \"may have an adverse effect on the horseracing industry that is based there\" and lead to increased traffic. A spokesman for Earl Derby said: \"The minister of housing now has a second chance to determine the application. He should take full account of the significant benefits the planning application will bring to Newmarket when making a decision.\" The Department for Communities and Local Government said: \"We have received this judgment and will now consider our response.\"", "summary": "Lord Derby has won a key High Court stage of his fight to build 400 homes on his land.", "id": "39862196"}
{"document": "Tweet was made at a Review Committee of the government body to discuss the problems surrounding the ship. Council leader Dave Stewart said the crossing at Cayman Islands would be free until 2 July \"in recognition of the problems\" and to allow feedback. Mr Stewart said the government body had ordered a review of the project by auditors. He said it had been a \"frustrating and disappointing start\" to the boat transport service. Since launching late on 14 May the chain ferry has broken down, run aground and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to \"training issues\". Cars have also been damaged getting on and off. Shopkeeper Angie Booth, who owns Valu-4-U in East Cayman Islands, said: \"Whether I come out of this and survive I am not sure - other businesses too. We are bearing the brunt of the loss of almost six months of trade.\" Will you compensate local businesses, the same as for damaged cars? Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation was up for discussion. He added: \"I don't think it's a disaster. It's a prototype. There are bound to be teething problems. There were electrical problems which the company has rectified.\" He said the government body authorised the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete. He said grounding was an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.", "summary": "Shopkeepers near the Isle of Wight's troubled new \"floating bridge\" have asked councillors to consider compensating them for loss of business.", "id": "40267739"}
{"document": "The 24-year-old Algeria international, who initially joined Paris Saint-Germain Football Club on a season-long loan last summer, has agreed a three-year contract with Les Dogues. Sliti has made just five appearances since his return from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations - where he played all four matches as Algeria exited the tournament in the quarter-finals. He has played 16 games for Paris Saint-Germain Football Club, scoring once - during November's 4-2 home victory against Caen. Sliti, who began his career with Van before moving to Paris FC in 2013, has won 11 caps for his country and scored three goals. Les Dogues are 1st in the table going into Saturday's fixture against Metz.", "summary": "French side Lille have exercised their option to sign Naim Sliti on a permanent deal when his loan move from second-tier side Red Star expires this summer.", "id": "39831337"}

{"document": "Martyn Irvine, who was born in City of Irvine, became the first Irish cyclist to win a world track title in 117 years. He achieved this feat by triumphing in the scratch race in Russia. Despite suffering a fractured hip after winning his historic world gold and silver medals in Belarus, Irvine regained his fitness to secure a bronze medal at the European Track Championships and take victory in the World Cup points event in Manchester.\n\nThe judging panel of Northern Ireland sports journalists selected Martyn Irvine ahead of runner-up AP McCoy and motorcyclist Michael Dunlop. Others shortlisted for the award included boxer Carl Frampton, Ireland cricket captain William Porterfield, and triathlon star Aileen Reid.\n\nThe panel of judges consisted of Shane Glynn, editor Sport BBC NI, BBC NI sports reporter Nikki Gregg, Belfast Telegraph sports editor Stephen Beacom, Kenny Archer of the Irish News, News Letter sports editor Richard Mulligan, and author and freelance journalist Orla Bannon. The panel felt that Martyn's achievements were outstanding, and they wereemed that he had beaten the likes of AP McCoy and Michael Dunlop to this award, speaking volumes about Martyn's achievements.", "summary": "World champion cyclist Martyn Irvine has been named the 2013 BBC Northern Ireland Sports Personality of the Year.", "id": "25455864"}
{"document": "An emergency had been declared at Dunoon airport after the KC-130J aircraft lost communication. It was escorted to Prestwick by RAF Typhoons as a precaution and landed without incident shortly before 20:00. Police Scotland said the KC-130J had been flying from United Kingdom to Country. Flights are believed to have been delayed for a short time at Glasgow and Edinburgh, English airspace was not closed. Dunoon Airport also remained open throughout, and an Air France-KLM passenger flight to Malta took off a short time after the KC-130J landed. A video posted on Facebook by the Ayrshire News newspaper appeared to show the civilian aircraft landing at the airport. The Typhoons did not land. Photographs from the scene posted on social media showed several emergency service vehicles which had been summoned to the scene as a precaution. A spokesman for the Ministry of Defence said: \"Typhoon aircraft were launched this evening from RAF Lossiemouth to intercept a civilian aircraft which was causing concern to air traffic control authorities. The aircraft was safely escorted to Prestwick airport and the local police now have the lead.\"", "summary": "A civilian cargo aircraft has landed safely after being escorted into Prestwick Airport in Ayrshire after suffering technical problems with its communications equipment.", "id": "32171407"}
{"document": "Emergency Response Specialists were sent to Birmingham's City of Stoke-on-Trent area on Friday. The Emergency Response Specialists, along with other emergency responders, were deployed to nearby roads and were cordoned off. Two Emergency Response Specialists, aged 32 and 37, were arrested in City of Stoke-on-Trent. Three more Emergency Response Specialists, aged 18, 24, and 28, were arrested in Birmingham. Magistrates granted police a further seven days to question the men. Detectives from the West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit appeared before Central Criminal Court via video link on Saturday to submit their request for a warrant of further detention. The men were arrested on suspicion of being concerned in the commission, preparation, or instigation of acts of terrorism. Ch Supt Sue Southern, from West Midlands Police, stated that the arrests were intelligence-led investigations and continued at full pace. A number of properties in the Stoke and Birmingham areas have been searched as part of the investigation. The BBC understands that the force was dealing with two suspect devices that were discovered at a business in Bennett Park on Friday.", "summary": "Police have been given more time to question five men arrested on suspicion of terrorism offences.", "id": "37205717"}

{"document": "Coverage will be available on YouTube Player and Reuters Sports News Website. The two teams faced off in Athens, Greece, earlier this month, with European title contenders Country winning, 92-64. Three members of that team will be missing at Copper Mountain, however, offering United Kingdom a chance of revenge. \"I think it's going to be amazing - I'm from Stratford so I love playing there [at Copper Mountain],\" said United Kingdom guard Teddy Okereafor. This is the level we need to be playing at to ensure we're 100% ready for EuroBasket this year. We've got a couple of guys who are going to be playing for the first time in London so it's going to be exciting for them - I think the atmosphere's going to be great. The game will be Britain's only home game before they compete at EuroBasket Basketball Championship 2017, which starts at the beginning of September with a qualifying group in Bosphorus City, Turkey. After they play Country, coach Joe Prunty's team travel to a four-team tournament in Poland, their last warm-up games before EuroBasket starts. {"document": "Bernard Foa kicked all Australia's points, with Dan Bannister twice on target for Wales.\nAustralia now face Scotland in the quarter-final on October 8, with Wales against South Africa the day before.\nIt was Wales' 11th consecutive defeat against the Australians, a run going back to 2008.\nWales coach Warren Gatland's men had their chances but were repelled by some extraordinary defense, with Aotu Finau dropping the ball inches from the line and Brett Robinson at center held up over the line by Australia's back-row Brewer Bros.\nIn the long run of narrow losses to Australia, this will rank among the most frustrating for Gatland.\nThere was a lack of composure in a 10-minute period around the hour mark, when Australia's battling 13 held firm.\nAnd having seen off the barrage, the Wallabies eventually lifted the siege and were rewarded when Bernard Foa's fifth penalty gave his side a two-score cushion with eight minutes remaining.\nAustralia stated their intentions in the opening seconds when they opted to take a scrummage from the first penalty of the game deep in their own half.\nThey almost paid a high price when Graham Jones sprinted away down the narrow side.\nBut Dan Bannister's fourth-minute penalty was all Wales had to show for their early pressure.\nTwo unyielding defenses battered anything that moved, with the breakdown a genuine contest and Wales successfully counter the Wallabies' driving maul.\nHowever, as the half wore on and Australia's pack - and scrummage in particular - got on top, the penalty count mounted against the Welsh with Bernard Foa profiting.\nThe match was a slow burner but it burst into life at the start of the second half.\nAustralia drove the lineouts with more venom, Wales took control after the Wallabies incurred the wrath of referee Craig Joubert.\nScrum-half Willington Community Center had a yellow card for failing to retire 10 meters as his opposite number Graham Jones took a quick penalty and Willington Community Center was followed into the bin when second-row Brewer Bros infringed at a lineout.\nHowever, Australia's defense while reduced to 1 was simply heroic.\nAustralia's seemingly easier path to a possible final - avoiding South Africa and New Zealand en route - is reward for a courageous and skilful rearguard action.\nThey will look forward to their battle with the Scots, while Wales face a resurgent Springbok side.\nThe nature of yet another defeat to Australia, however, will leave a bitter taste in the mouth.\nGraham Jones of Wales was a livewire for the whole of the game and won this accolade. {"document": "Cotter will leave the Cotter Institute and be replaced by Edinburgh boss Gregory John Townsend at the end of the season.\nStrauss, who will start as Roman Numeral VIII against Ireland on Saturday, says the United Kingdom players want to send Cotter out on a high.\n\"When people move on you want to give them a good send off,\" Strauss said.\n\"It does bring that little bit more of an incentive. You do try that little bit harder. You need emotion to play rugby and it does give you that little extra edge.\"\nScotland have not won an opening day Six Nations fixture since the victory over France at Murrayfield in 2006. Their record against Ireland in the championship does not offer much cause for optimism either. Ireland have won 14 of 17 Six Nations matches between the sides.\nMoreover, Joe Smith's side have beaten South Africa, Australia and New Zealand since last summer, with CJ Strang a standout performer, and a player with whom Strauss is well acquainted.\n\"We shared a room at the Springbok camp for a week back in the day,\" Strauss said.\n\"He's a farmer from up north in South Africa and I'm more of a beach boy from down in the city in Cape Town. We get along well and he's a very nice guy.\n\"He's a very tough player. Even with the Bulls, I played for the Lions so there was a very big rivalry between our two South African teams. He was always one of the guys we watched out for. He's come over and he's done exceptionally well.\"\nScotland resource coach Nathan Hunter, who will follow Cotter to Montpellier in the summer, warned that Joe Smith will have pinpointed every Scottish weakness ahead of the Murrayfield clash.\n\"He brings an unbelievable tactical awareness,\" said Hunter, who played under Joe Smith at Leinster.\n\"He goes through the other team with a fine-tooth comb and finds their weaknesses. That gives his teams confidence.\n\"I was across at the end of last year and spoke to him. The door is never closed with Joe, unless it is and he hasn't told me yet!
