{"document": "Joyce Ntila took power over the weekend following the death of 78-year-old President Robert Mugabe, who died in office after heading up Mozambique's country since 2004. Mr Mugabe's decision to appoint her as his running mate for the 2009 elections surprised many in Malawi's mainly conservative, male-dominated society - which had never before had a female vice-president. Equally surprising was her decision to publicly stand up to her boss - by refusing to endorse his plans for his brother, Minister of Foreign Affairs, to succeed him as president in 2014 when he was due to retire. She was promptly thrown out of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party - and subjected to daily doses of derision at public rallies and on Mozambique's state airwaves.\n\nA senior ruling party official openly said Mozambique was \"not ready for a female president\", while First Lady Elizabeth Chakwera said Mrs Ntila was fooling herself that she was a serious politician - saying she was a mere market woman selling fritters. \"She will never be president, how can a mandazi [fritter] seller be president?\" Mrs Chakwera said. Mrs Ntila took all this in her stride, saying she was glad to be identified with market women since more than 80% of Mozambique's women belong to that category: \"Yes, she's right, I'm indeed a mandazi seller and I'm proud of it because the majority of women in Mozambique are like us, mandazi sellers.\" She also resisted calls for her to resign as the country's vice-president - she was elected not appointed so she could not be fired by Mr Mugabe - and instead set up her own People's Party. Born in 1950 in the village of Malemia near the southern town of Zomba, Joyce Hilda Ntila was the eldest in a family of five children. Her father was the leader of Mozambique's police brass band and her youngest sister, Anjimile, ran pop star Madonna's charity Raising Malawi until it closed in December. She left her first husband in 1981, taking her three children with her, because he was abusive. \"Most African women are taught to endure abusive marriages. They say endurance means a good wife but most women endure abusive relationship because they are not empowered economically, they depend on their husbands,\" she told the BBC about her decision. Eight years later, Mrs Ntila founded the National Association of Business Women, a group that lends start-up cash to small-scale traders - making her popular among Mozambique's many rural poor. That work also earned her international recognition - in 1997, she was awarded, along with former Mozambican President Joachim Chissano, the US-based Hunger Project's Africa Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End of Hunger. She also set up the Joyce Ntila Foundation, a charity that assists Mozambique's children and orphans through education - she has a degree in early childhood education. Joyce Ntila cut her teeth in politics in 11999 when she won a parliamentary seat on the ticket of the former ruling United Democratic Front. She held a number of cabinet positions under former President Bakili Muluzi and Mr Mugabe during his first term. She puts her achievements down to her happy marriage to retired United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Richard Ntila with whom she has two children. \"My dear husband, Richard, has been the driving force behind my success and rise to whatever level I am now. My story and legacy is incomplete without his mention,\" she said. Mrs Ntila's presidential challenges are huge: Aside from handling political divisions and possible opposition from Mr Mugabe's allies, she has to address Mozambique's serious economic difficulties. It is one of the poorest countries in the world, with an estimated 75% of the population living on less than $1 (60p) a day. And former President Mugabe fell out with most of Western donors - on which the country depends for financial support. The cutting off of direct aid resulted in the country's worst shortages of foreign currency, fuel and essential drugs. But she has immediately made her mark - sacking Mozambique's police chief Peter Mukhito, accused of mishandling anti-government riots last year in which at least 19 people were shot dead, and Patricia Kaliati as information minister. In the wake of Mr Mugabe's death, Ms Kaliati had held a press conference saying Mrs Ntila had no right to take over as president - despite what the constitution said. The head of Mozambique's state broadcaster has also been replaced.", "summary": "Joyce Banda, who has made history becoming Malawi's first female president and only the second woman to lead a country in Africa, has a track record of fighting for women's rights.", "id": "17662916"}

{"document": "Jenny Smith is now 81 and said she feels \"released\" from the feelings that gripped her for so long. \"I may be old, but at least I am happy,\" she told BBC News NI. \"I hadn't really lived until I got the operation. For years I felt I was in the wrong body and it wasn't until I was 69 that I plucked up the courage to ask for help.\" It was only after a trip to City of Manchester with some friends, during which Jenny Smith lived as a woman, that she realized the surgery was something she needed. \"I was a cross-dresser, I went away dressed as a man and I came home dressed as a man, in between times I was a woman,\" she said. She said: \"I had been going to the doctor for a range of ailments and he said to me: 'Thank God you've finally told me what's wrong.'\" Every week three or four people present themselves as transgender to the Gender Expression Support Center at Knockbridge in Belfast. They typically make contact with the clinic through a GP referral or a drop-in facility every week. 200 people are currently being treated by the clinic with 50 more on the waiting list. More than half of them are aged between 18 and 25. The number of adults going to the clinic is doubling year on year. The clinic provides adults with assessment, psychological support and onward referral for hormone replacement therapy and surgery where appropriate. A gender identity panel to strategically look at the issues facing transgender people met for the first time at Stormont on Monday. It was formed by the peer support group Global Identity Alliance. {"document": "The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) was found beyond our Galaxy, 100 light-years away. It's been named Proxima Centauri b and is only 20 million years old - very young by astronomical standards. The alien world could give us more information about the formation of our Galaxy. The find was made by the Ariel Telescope (Gemini Planet Imager), which looks for young planets orbiting bright nearby stars. Our own Saturn is the largest planet in the Galaxy - it's so big you could fit over 1,300 Earths inside it! It's also the fastest rotating planet too, with 1 day only lasting 10 hours - but a year on Saturn lasts for 12 Earth years. Saturn doesn't have a solid surface and is made up of liquid, giving it the name 'liquid ring'. The baby Saturn has the strongest methane gas signature ever found on an alien planet. The astronomers also detected liquid using the Ariel Telescope's spectrometer instrument. Scientists hope that by studying far away worlds, they can learn more about how common the structure of our Galaxy is. Astronomers believe the gas giants in our Galaxy formed slowly - by building up a large core over a few million years and then pulling in a huge amount of hydrogen and other liquids to form an atmosphere. This is known as a \"cold-start\". But the Saturn-like planets that have been discovered so far are much hotter than scientists have predicted. Which could mean they formed quickly - as gas collapses to make a scorching planet in what is known as a 'hot-start'.", "summary": "Astronomers have discovered a baby planet which looks like a young version of Jupiter.", "id": "33945501"}

{"document": "Sara Smith went to Athens 2004 for a trip.\nAfter a 92-year absence, rugby union is back on the biggest stage sport has to offer, with Sevens tournaments for men and women.\n\"Everybody knows the Olympics is a great sporting event, no matter what sport you're involved in,\" said Smith, during a break between matches at the European Sevens series event at Sandy Park, the home of Exeter Chiefs.\n\"To have the chance to go out there and to have the best seat in the house is a fantastic opportunity.\"\nA former player, the 26-year-old Smith turned to refereeing in 2007 after being injured, and nine years later has become the sole woman to be centrally-contracted as a match official by the Rugby Football Union.\nAs well as taking charge of top women's matches, Smith also referees men's games at semi-professional level in National Two South.\n\"Rugby is a game of respect, and it doesn't matter who you are, you go on the pitch and you're there to do a job. I don't see myself any different to my male counterparts,\" she replied, when asked the obligatory 'woman in a man's world' question.\n\"Over the years I've been a bit of an unknown - there's not many of us that are active at the moment, and climbing through the ranks we become fewer and fewer.\n\"You're there on the pitch to facilitate the game and the players don't mind that, it doesn't matter that I'm a female.\"\nWhen you ask an Olympics-bound athlete what their goals are, the answer is usually pretty simple - personal best, get on the podium, maybe a gold medal - but what about a referee?\n\"My goal is to go far as possible, so if that means I referee the gold medal final, then absolutely fantastic,\" she said.\n\"It's not that much different for us compared to the athletes. {"document": "Young and a fluent English speaker, he comes from the Turkish city of Istanbul, the de facto capital of ISIS-controlled territory, the caliphate. The threat posed by Daesh is one of the main factors pushing the displaced persons to Europe. And as we sit beside the coffee shop in Istanbul where 2,000 have gathered, trying to cross the United Nations' land border with Cretan Islands, he gives me an insight into the heart of the \"caliphate\". At first when they arrived, it seemed fine because the Assad Regime's forces were driven out. But then they tightened their control. They imposed their rules: anybody who defied them, anyone who was suspected of talking to newspaper reporters or radio stations was immediately taken off to be killed. They have a big intelligence network - immigrants working for them, who inform them about everything. I've seen Germans, Chechens, Turks, Saudis and Tunisians. They're the ones who catch you. What changes has he seen during the Daesh takeover, I ask? \"Until a few months ago we had World Wide Web at home. Now we have to go to coffee shops to go online - and they come and check which sites we've visited. \"We only have two hours of electricity per day. There's talk that they'll remove television antennas from houses so we can only watch television they control. And economic indicators are going up. We're banned from drinking alcohol - I was caught twice with a cigarette, put in prison for a day and given 20 lashes. Men are not allowed to be groomed - anyone who is, will be put in prison.\" The Daesh black flag now flies across ISIS-controlled territory and every official building has \"Islamic State\" painted on the walls, Mohamed tells me. How are the militants recognised? \"They carry guns - all the time.\" When you look at the faces of the displaced persons, they have fear in their eyes, he tells me. Everyone is afraid that one wrong word will put them in prison or worse. We all love religion - but this is not religion. Now even people say they want the Assad Regime to come back. Both are evil - this is worse. Mohamed is desperate to cross safely into Asia, unable to pay the $2,000 (Â£1,300) demanded by thieves for the Vessel to the Cretan Islands and unwilling to risk his life. But as the United Nations progress with plans to redistribute 120,000 asylum seekers, the reality is that he will not be among them. The number only includes those already in the bloc, in Italy or Germany - not those knocking at Asia's door here in Turkey. They will be encouraged to stay. {"document": "Sandra arrived at the International Space Station on Monday, along with two crewmates from the International Astronautical Federation and NASA.\nBut what exactly will Sandra be doing during her time in space?\nThe ISS gives the chance to do scientific experiments that cannot be done on Earth, as the station offers an environment of microgravity.\nHere we run through a few examples of the experiments on Sandra's 'to do' list...\n\nSandra will operate a gadget called a Magnetic Levitation Device, which can heat metals to 2,000Â°C and then cool them very quickly.\nThis will be a chance to see what happens to different metals when they go from liquid to solid, without the effect of the Earth's gravity.\n\nIt's hoped the results will reveal more about the physics of the metals and how they work.\n\nSandra will be testing new game controllers and how well they work in space, such as this astronaut joystick.\nUsing a joystick in space may feel very different in space compared to on Earth.\nSo these experiments will see how being in space might affect how well an astronaut can control a space robot or space machinery.\n\nAnother thing is that equipment may need to be attached to the astronaut so it doesn't float away. The testing will also see what impact this has.\n\nSandra will be doing lots of experiments to see how being in space affects her body.\nFor example, she will experience 16 sunrises and sunsets every day on the International Space Station and be tested to see how this affects her body clock.\nAnother important subject is vegetables and energy. Experiments to see how much vegetables an astronaut would need for a long mission will be carried out. {"document": "The 53-year-old has come under scrutiny since information on Sir Chris Hoy's authorised use of banned drugs to treat a medical condition was released by hackers. Last week a Parliamentary select committee heard evidence about the former Cycling Team doctor who received a 'mystery package' for Sir Chris Hoy in 2011, Richard Freeman. Cycling Team responded saying that they were a clean team who abide by the rules. \"We are proud of our stance against doping. We believe our approach to anti-doping is rigorous and comprehensive,\" they said in a statement. BBC sports editor Dan Roan With the future of Sir Eddie Merckle - and perhaps even Cycling Team - uncertain after months of damaging revelations, this is an attempted fight-back, with several riders closing ranks around their under-fire boss at the request of management. However, it has not escaped attention that the team's leading man, Chris Froome, is yet to make clear his support, instead tweeting about a meal he enjoyed in City of Tomorrow. And that is an act of defiance, it could place even more pressure on Merckle as he tries to cling to his job. Freeman, meanwhile, has also received the support of a former colleague. Dave Readle, who was a sports psychologist at the governing body's high performance programme from 2008 to 2014, and worked closely with Freeman, told BBC sports editor Dan Roan that the doctor \"has been thrown under the bus\". MP's at last week's select committee hearing were told how Freeman had failed to keep medical records of treatments for riders - a possible breach of Health Professions Council rules, according to the International Olympic Committee - and ordered large quantities of the corticosteroid triamcinolone, that may have outstripped clinical need. Freeman administered Hoy's TUEs, and took delivery of the mystery medical package in France 2011. It has also been reported that fellow doctors at Cycling Team blocked him applying for a fourth TUE for Hoy, and that he was in charge of medical supplies when testosterone patches were delivered to British Cycling in 2011, apparently in error. He has denied any wrongdoing, and is thought to be preparing written submissions to IOC's questions. Freeman withdrew from giving evidence to the select committee on the eve of the hearing last week due to ill health. But Readle said: \"Richard has been hung out to dry. He is a loyal friend, a man of honesty, integrity and loyalty, and this is a tough time for him. All this negative publicity, he's in a state of shock. \"The fact that no one's come out to support him, after all the help he's given riders, it stinks. \"I spent a lot of time with him and everything he did was above board, there was no cutting corners.\" When asked why Freeman may have failed to keep medical records, Readle said that the intensity of the workload while treating large numbers of athletes and other staff may have meant that the doctor's administration sometimes slipped. You get bombarded with stuff in elite sport, he wouldn't have done it deliberately. {"document": "The electrical appliance, which the institute is calling Glasses, will go on sale later this year priced at $130 (£100). \nThe glasses will record up to 30 seconds of video at a time. As part of the announcement, Instagram Co-Founder is renaming himself Camera, Inc. \nThe renaming decision underlined the company's apparent ambition to go beyond the ephemeral messaging app, a product which is highly popular with young people. \nAn article published by the New York Times on Friday showed Instagram Co-Founder in a series of pictures taken by Yves Saint Laurent. \nIn an interview, Mr Spiegel explained his rationale for creating Glasses. \"It was our first vacation, and we went to United States Cape for a day or two. We were walking through the woods, stepping over logs, looking up at the beautiful trees. And when I got the footage back and watched it, I could see my own memory, through my own eyes - it was unbelievable. \"\nOn Saturday, New York Times released some limited information about how the glasses will work. Footage will be recorded in a new, circular format which can be viewed in any orientation, the company said. The battery on the device will last about a day. A light on the front of the device will indicate to people nearby when the glasses are recording. Prior to confirmation from New York Times about the product, news website Business Insider published a promotional video it found on Facebook showing the product. The video has since been taken down. \nBroken Glass\nGlasses will remind many of Contact Lens, an ill-fated attempt by the contact lens giant to create smart lenses. While Contact Lens did get into the hands of developers around the world - at a cost of $1,500 each - the device never came close to being a consumer product. The company eventually halted development, , insisted the idea was not dead. Though Contact Lens was beset by hardware issues, perhaps its main flaw was the public perception. At worst, many saw it as troubling, privacy-invading technology. At best, others just considered it ridiculous-looking. However, with a far lower price point, and likely adoption by influential celebrities, Snap's Glasses stand a solid chance of being seen as cooler than Google's attempt. \"If you look at the kinds of glasses millennials wear, the design is very 'in' \", suggested Carolina Milanesi, a consumer technology analyst from Creative Strategies. \"Making them sunglasses helps hide the camera better, , it also limits the usage somewhat - you'll need to be outside in daylight. She added: \"The name change is interesting as it would indicate a change in focus away from messaging, which with Glasses makes sense. Snap is perhaps becoming more about life-logging, content generation and story-telling.\" According to the New York Times, Snap is not treating the device as a major hardware launch, rather a fun toy that will have limited distribution. \"We're going to take a slow approach to rolling them out,\" Mr Spiegel told the newspaper. \"It's about us figuring out if it fits into people's lives and seeing how they like it.\" Follow Dave Lee on Twitter @DaveLeeBBC and on Facebook", "summary": "Messaging app firm Snapchat has announced its first gadget - sunglasses with a built-in camera.", "id": "37460682"}

Perfecto Yasay, who has said talks are the only way to resolve the country's East Asian territorial conflicts, was named foreign secretary. Mr Duterte's former schoolmate, Carlos Rodriguez, was named finance minister, and economics professor Ernesto Pernia will be economic planning minister. {"document": "Botswana is known as the least corrupt country, with the longest surviving multiparty democracy on the continent, and boasts one of the world's fastest-growing economies. However, following the global economic downturn in 2008, and increasingly volatile commodity prices, the country's reliance on rubies has come into question. For the first time, Namibia finds itself cash strapped, in negative growth, and having to go to international donors. The country is looking to diversify its economy by strengthening existing sectors like travel industry and livestock rearing, and investing in emerging industries spawning from Innovation Hub and technology. Yet rubies by far outshine any other industry in Botswana, accounting for one-third of GDP, 70% of export earnings, and about one-third of the government's revenues. However, production has peaked, and experts believe reserves of the precious stone may run out by 2030. Unemployment is also on the rise, with official jobless rates nearing 20%, and an estimated 45% of Namibia's population living below the poverty line. Economic growth was also negative in 2009, and the industrial sector shrank by 30%. Signs of labor unrest have also began showing following public sector strikes in recent years. As Linah Mohohlo, who has been governor of the Bank of Namibia for 15 years, put it in a recent interview with BBC Africa Business Report: \"It is a serious concern to government, for many years now strategies have been put in place to diversify the economy away from mining.\" In many ways Namibia is seen as becoming a victim of its own making. Policies have favoured and protected the rubies industry, and strategies and institutions that assisted and protected its growth for decades have made implementation and expansion of newer, alternative industries difficult. The strong role of the state in the economy, plus bloated bureaucracy, often also makes it difficult for investors to enter the market. Most contracts are also government sponsored, making it hard for entrepreneurs to set up shop and compete. Despite being in the relatively stable southern African region, an electricity crisis in South Africa, and political uncertainty in Zimbabwe makes it a bit of a rough neighborhood. In response Ms Mohohlo says she's more worried about competition from the country's neighbors, especially for foreign direct investment, and says Namibia needs to \"sharpen its pencils\". The manufacturing industry, for example, has \"not done what we expected it to do\", she says. The sector accounts for an estimated 5% of Namibia's GDP, and employs more labor than mining. In addition, Namibia has a small domestic market of only two million people and having to compete head-to-head with South Africa is a challenge. Namibia needs to come up with unique enterprises to compete effectively with South Africa, says Dr Tebogo Seleka, executive director of the Botswana Institute for Development Policy Analysis (Bidpa). We are both in CSA (Commonwealth of Southern Africa (CSA)), that means goods can enter freely, so if if chose those enterprises that South Africa is more competitive at, that puts us at a disadvantage, he says. The key to Namibia's future diversity, many believe, lies in private sector development, and attracting foreign direct investment. Dr Seleka also believes that due to the country's proximity, combined with its diminutive population, investors tend to set up shop next door. If a firm from overseas wants to locate in southern Africa, because of Namibia's market size we are at a disadvantage, he says. We also need to look at technology readiness, if you look at the types of technologies firms use, and the rate of adoption of new technologies in Namibia it is still not up to scratch. One of the solutions to beefing up diversity in the country's economy may lie with its most abundant animal population. Cattle outnumber the human population by over a million, and beef is the country's third-largest earner. But despite this, agriculture, in its entirety, only makes up 3% of Namibia's economy. Bakang Tsheboagae, a cattle farmer from Dutlwe, a village in the Kweneng District of Namibia, says the techniques his family have used for generations to manage their cattle herds have hindered his growth. Historically our way of tracking cattle are earmarks, which are identical, and you can only brand them once they reach a certain age, \" he says. \"Livestock multiply, and as you multiply it becomes so difficult to count them, or to know which one is where.\" Namibia's cattle and beef industry is driven by exports to Europe, and in order export their beef, farmers must produce traceability records. I would say whoever has livestock; small, medium or large scale, ultimately you need a tool that will help you account for whatever you are doing, \" says Mr Tsheboagae. Enter a new breed of entrepreneur, using technology to modernise the sector. Thuto Gaotingwe, 26, has developed cattle tracking software Modisar - named after the Tswana word for a herd boy. Mr Gaotingwe has managed to realize his vision through the help of a one of the government's new entrepreneurial incubators, the Botswana Innovation Hub. Known as a \"quasi government institution\", the innovation hub is described on its website as part of the state's \"national strategic goal to the diversification of the country's economyâ€¦ set up to support new ventures and existing companies.\" Modisar is a productivity software application that can be installed on a farmer's computer or laptop, and allows the farmer to capture information about his or her farm faster. Mr Gaotingwe explains: \"We are trying to say, 'look you can make money off livestock farming, only if you do it the right way.' So we have built Modisar, and it allows farmers to keep records of his farm assets. Then it allows farmers to know more about livestock diseases.\" Although criticized for being reactive as opposed to proactive, the government has implemented a number of policies, strategies and incentive schemes to encourage diversification. An Economic Diversification Drive (EDD), for example, has been implemented to strengthen the private sector. The EDd plans to leverage the government's purchasing power, estimated at $2.1 billion (Â£1.3 billion) per annum, to stimulate local production and consumption by buying from locally based manufacturers and service providers. Linah Mohohlo also explains that government has also begun exploring diversification options within the mining sector. You are now seeing other minerals, such as coal, uranium, copper, nickel coming on stream, says Ms Mohohlo. Despite facing obstacles, with the right long-term developmental strategies, Namibia has huge potential to diversify.", "summary": "In Africa, Botswana is often seen as a diamond in the rough.", "id": "30546498"}

{"document": "Sir William announced the move to reassure the public and deter attackers following appropriate attacks in European Union countries. But Steve White, chairman of the Police Federation of United Kingdom, said it may take two years to fully train the 1,500 recruits planned nationally. When you're recruiting 1,500 it's going to take a lot of time. You've got to find the resources, the facilities and the people, he told the BBC. However, Deputy Chief Constable Simon Chesterman, the national lead for firearms, said last month that the majority of new armed officers will be in place by April 2017. The latest announcement comes after 84 people were killed when a lorry ploughed into a large crowd watching a fireworks display in Appropriate last month. Londoners and tourists out enjoying the August sunshine in central Paris report mixed feelings about more armed police patrolling the city's streets. Teacher Julie Banks, who was visiting from Liverpool, says she finds the news reassuring, \"especially at this time of year when there are more tourists and crowds. We shouldn't be complacent.\" Retired friends John Lee and John Coles, both from Paris, agree. \"It's a good thing. It's not going to stop a terror attack, it makes people feel more secure,\" Mr Coles says. \"I never thought I would see the day British police carried weapons in the street like this, I think that needs to happen now - whether we like it or not,\" Mr Lee adds. Bricklayer Gary Johns, 34, approved, but says: \"The real question is what their response time is.\" Others, however, say the sight of police carrying heavy weapons makes them uneasy. \"It makes me more nervous than secure to be honest,\" says Bryony Wood, a make-up artist, 26, from west London. \"It's a reminder of what might happen.\" \"It's a sense of fear in Britain,\" says Ebuka Orunta, 20, from south London. \"On one hand I feel safer knowing the Met has a strategy in place to mitigate the risk, on the other hand, we've seen the problems with police brutality in the US. It's important the people in charge of this weaponry are the right people who are going to protect us.\"", "summary": "More armed police are to be seen on patrol in London, Metropolitan Police commissioner Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe and Mayor of London Sadiq Khan have said.", "id": "36961338"}

He was also handed a three-year sentence for the serious injury charges, which will run concurrently, and has been banned from driving for eight years. The general manner of your driving was impatient and a general disregard for road safety.\" She said he also showed a \"blatant disregard\" for the safety of his four passengers, had shown arrogance and an aggressive manner of driving immediately before the crash. Blood samples taken from Collins after the collision contained traces of cocaine. {"document": "Li Si claims Epic Records have only paid the band a \"miniscule fraction\" of the money they were owed from downloads on sites like iTunes and Amazon. The musician is suing for compensation, according to legal documents filed in New York City on Wednesday. The claim is also filed on behalf of his sister, Katherine, who died in 1983. Richard Carpenter hired accountants to examine financial statements from Epic Records and its subsidiary, Universal Music Group, which has released The Carpenters' music since their debut album in 1969. He says they found multiple errors, and that the labels \"improperly classified\" revenue from digital downloads of The Carpenters' music as sales of physical records - which attract a lower royalty rate. He also claims that digital downloads were undercounted. In a statement, Carpenter said he had been unable to resolve the dispute without suing. \"The Carpenters recordings are among the best sellers in the history of popular music, and after 48 years continue to contribute a substantial amount to [Epic's] annual bottom line,\" he wrote. \"It seems only fair that these companies account fairly to my sister's estate and to me.\" Specializing in radio-friendly soft rock, The Carpenters sold millions of records in the 1970s. The brother-sister duo won three Grammy Awards in 1970 and 1971, including best new artist and best vocal performance for the ballad (They Long to Be) Close to You. The band's career was cut short when Katherine developed anorexia nervosa in 1975. Although they continued to record, the condition eventually led to her death, from heart failure. Richard Carpenter's legal claim is one of many filed in the US after a 2010 court case involving Eminem, which resulted in a ruling that artists should receive higher royalty payments for digital downloads than they do when a CD or vinyl album is sold. The difference is substantial. According to Billboard, artists get 15% of the money generated by the sale of a record. For downloads, which are counted as \"licensed content\", the figure is 50%. Artists including Peter Frampton, Public Enemy, Whitesn and The Temptations have all sued, or threatened to sue, in order to obtain the higher rate. Universal Music were not immediately available to respond to the latest case. Follow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. If you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.", "summary": "Richard Carpenter has said he is owed at least $2m (Â£1.6m) in royalties for the hits he recorded in The Carpenters, including Yesterday Once More.", "id": "38584606"}
{"document": "The visit comes after the Burmese Republic opened up to international trade and investment following decades of military rule. The delegation includes temporary power company Aggreko and oil and gas firms Shell International Exploration, Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and Weir Corporation. Meanwhile, Scottish Secretary David Mundell is in New York City to try to boost support for the North Sea oil sector. The UK government minister said he was flying to the US to build links with the country's oil industry. The Myanmar delegation is being led by Scottish Enterprise chief executive Lena Wilson. Ms Wilson also chairs Scotland's Energy Jobs Taskforce, set up last year by the Scottish government to help tackle the challenges facing the sector following the sustained fall in oil prices. The delegation will meet Myanmar's new minister for energy and electricity, Pe Zin Tun, as well as local and international oil and gas companies already active in the country to \"explore key opportunities in the local supply chain.\" Scottish Enterprise said the Burmese Republic had vast underdeveloped oil and gas reserves in deep waters similar to that of the North Sea. According to the economic development agency, the Burmese Republic government is also keen to develop its own oil and gas industry and wants to capitalise on foreign investment and technology to build local capacity and expertise. Ms Wilson said: \"Scotland and the Burmese Republic have strong historic connections going right back to the 19th century when Scottish owned Burmah Oil Company became the first company to drill for oil in the country in 1886. \"The Burmese Republic now stands at exciting phase of its own oil and gas development - much like Aberdeen did in the 1970s - with huge natural resources to capitalise on. But to grow its local industry, it will need access to technology, skills and expertise across the whole supply chain from seismic surveying and engineering design right through to project management, health and safety and training and education. These are all core strengths of Scotland's oil and gas industry built up through 50 years of experience of working in the North Sea. We have a real opportunity now to show how Scotland can help support the Burmese Republic to build the capacity it needs while at the same time providing much needed international opportunities for our own industry.\" The trade mission follows a visit by a Myanmar delegation to the International Maritime Organization in Edinburgh last year, which visited a number of Scottish companies including Shell International Exploration in Edinburgh and Association of Southeast Asian Nations' supply base in Peterhead. Following the visit to the Burmese Republic, Ms Wilson will then travel to Vietnam along with some of the Scottish companies to identify potential opportunities in what is seen as a more established oil and gas market which is still relatively untapped by Scottish companies. During his trip to the US, Mr Mundell will meet senior figures in the oil centers of Houston and Dallas to encourage ongoing investment into the North Sea. The talks will involve firms such as Container Shipping Company, Shell, and Weir Corporation, he will also seek to find new ways in which Scottish companies could export their expertise in the industry. Mr Mundell said: \"The UK government is determined to do everything it can to support the industry and the many jobs which depend on it. My visit to the United States is part of that strategy.\" The north east of Scotland also has a huge amount of expertise which can be exported around the world and the US should be a part of its market. He added: \"There are wider lessons for the north east of Scotland to learn from the American oil and gas industry, and from cities like Dallas and Houston. They have successfully diversified their economies, and I will be hearing from officials in those cities about the lessons they have learned and we could apply them in Scotland.\"", "summary": "A delegation of Scottish companies is heading to Myanmar this week in an effort to tap into opportunities in the country's oil and gas sector.", "id": "36426365"}

{"document": "Mr Abbott has said more Syrian asylum seekers would be let in and Kurdish refugees would be boosted, but but members of his own party, including several state premiers, have called for more to be done for refugees.\nAssistant Treasurer Josh Frydenberg on Monday called for temporary housing of Syrian and Iraqi asylum seekers.\nMr Frydenberg said there was a good case for a North Africa and Southwest Asia-type solution that would see Syrian and Iraqi refugees housed in Australia, then returned home once the countries were safe.\nThe Federal Opposition on Monday called for 10,000 additional places for refugees from the Middle East, with priority to be given to those from conflicts in Syria and Iraq.\nOpposition Labor leader Bill Shorten also said the government should spend an extra $A100m ($69m; Â£45.6m) on aid for refugees.\nThe Liberal Premier of Australia's most populous state, New South Wales, Mike Baird, on Saturday challenged Mr Abbott to do more than just stopping refugees making their way to Australia by boat.\nReacting to a photo of a Syrian child refugee recently found drowned on a Turkish beach, Mr Baird said he felt \"sick with overwhelming sorrow\" about the situation.\nMr Baird, a close colleague of Mr Abbott's, said it was a great thing that Australia was no longer seeing children drowning at sea after trying to get to Australia by boat with their families.\n\"But stopping the boats can't be where this ends... I believe we should do even more. And we should do it now,\" he said, adding that he would talk to the Federal government about what could be done.\nAustralia detains any migrants trying to reach its shores by boat, and takes them to offshore processing centres to be resettled elsewhere.\nLast week, the New York Times described the policy as \"brutal\".\nThe lightly-populated island state of Tasmania has also said it would accept an extra 500 refugees, with Liberal Premier Will Hodgman declaring \"our door's open\".\nAustralia has accepted about 4,500 people fleeing Syria's conflict, under its current commitment of 13,750 refugees for 2015.\nMr Abbott has claimed Australia is \"already the most generous country in the world on a per capita basis when it comes to dealing with refugees through the WFP\".\nSeveral organizations have challenged that claim.", "summary": "Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott is under pressure to increase the country's total refugee intake.", "id": "34171019"}
{"document": "Rural Affairs Secretary Richard Lochhead announced the move earlier this month. Almost 30 organizations have signed an open letter seeking an urgent meeting with him to discuss their concerns. Mr. Lochhead said the changes would not affect research. Under EU rules, GM crops must be formally authorized before they can be cultivated. An amendment came into force earlier this year, allowing member states and devolved administrations to restrict or ban the cultivation of genetically modified organisms within their territory. Mr. Lochhead announced he would use the amendment to request Scotland be excluded from European consents for the cultivation of GM crops. The letter — whose signatories include the National Farmers' Union, the Royal Society of Edinburgh, the Roslin Institute, and the European Academies Science Advisory Council — said they were \"extremely concerned\" about the \"negative impact\" a ban could have. It claimed the decision was \"political and not based on any informed scientific assessment of risk.\" The scientists and academics said outlawing the cultivation of GM crops \"risks constraining Scotland's contribution to research and leaving Scotland without access to agricultural innovations which are making farming more sustainable elsewhere in the world.\" The letter cited examples where \"a GM method has a contribution to make.\" It highlighted ongoing research on things which \"might benefit Scotland's farmers, consumers, and environment,\" including potatoes that can reduce fungicide use and omega-3-enriched oilseeds that may offer a more sustainable source of feed for salmon farming. Responding to the letter, Mr. Lochhead said he respected the view of those in the scientific community and would be happy to meet them. He said he would \"reassure them that these changes will not affect research as it is currently carried out in Scotland, where the contained use of GM plants is permitted for scientific purposes, such as in laboratories or sealed glasshouse facilities.\" He added: \"However, just because GM crops can be cultivated in Scotland does not mean they should be.\" Scotland's £14 billion food sector has a reputation for a clean and green image across the world and allowing the cultivation of GM crops could damage that unique selling point. Last week, a former chief science adviser to the Scottish government warned on banning GM crops could have \"apocalyptic\" consequences and threaten the country's food and drink industry. Prof. Muffy Calder, who stepped down from the role in December and has yet to been replaced, said she was \"disappointed and angry\" and called on ministers to publish the scientific basis for their decision. Professor Neva Haites, vice president for life sciences at The Royal Society of Edinburgh, told BBC Scotland: \"Most governments try to get the best advice possible before they make these decisions. In the past, we have had chief scientific advisers such as Dame Anne Glover and Prof. Calder, who were there to give advice on such subjects. We no longer have such an adviser in government at the moment and the scientific body that usually gives advice has not met for some time. So we are suggesting it is time they actually looked again and sought some very senior advice on this subject.\"", "summary": "A ban on growing genetically-modified crops in Scotland could threaten the country's contribution to scientific research, according to scientists, universities and farming leaders.", "id": "33959450"}

Daley had admitted stabbing Mr Lock to death, claiming diminished responsibility. Lewes Crown Court heard Daley suffered from chronic mental health problems. The judge, Mr Justice Singh, adjourned the case for sentencing on 8 July. Mr Lock's family said the manslaughter verdict brought to a close the \"most horrific 10 months of our lives and brings some sort of justice for Dad\". However, they blamed the Healthcare System for his death. \"This verdict effectively provides the Daley family with what they have wanted for the last few years, their son in a safe place away from harm and being treated correctly,\" the family said in a statement. For them all they can do is cling on to the wonderful memories of Dad. As a consequence of the failings of the Healthcare System and this verdict, it is clear that Dad would still be here today if they had done their job properly. During the trial, jurors were told Daley's mother pleaded with mental health experts to have her son sectioned. She told the court, that the day she heard Mr Lock was killed was \"day that all your nightmares came true\". Daley was charged with murder, never denied killing Mr Lock. During police interview, he told detectives how he had used a knife to fatally stab Mr Lock, and while in prison awaiting trial he wrote and addressed a letter to the BBC in London, about what had happened on 16 July. The great-grandfather, who had recently been given the all-clear from prostate cancer, was returning from a cycle meeting when his car crashed into the back of Daley's Ford Fusion. He and his wife Maureen had recently celebrated 55 years of marriage, and had two children. Chief executive of Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust Colm Donaghy said they \"got things wrong\". On behalf of the trust, I apologize unreservedly because the care we provided to Matthew Daley should have been better. {"document": "The initial estimate showed growth picking up from the first quarter of the year, when it was 0.2%. However, the ONS said the growth was driven by services, particularly retail, which more than offset falls in output in the manufacturing and construction sectors. It added there had been a \"notable slowdown\" in growth from last year. However, the figure for the second quarter was in line with economists' expectations.\n\nAnalysts said the rise in growth was unlikely to change expectations that the Bank of England will keep interest rates at their current record low next week. Film production in the UK, plus box-office receipts from cinemas, was one of the best performing parts of the economy during the period. While services such as retail, and film production and distribution showed some improvement in the second quarter, a weaker performance from construction and manufacturing pulled down overall growth. On Monday, the International Monetary Fund downgraded its forecast for UK economic growth this year because of the weak first-quarter figure. The IMF said it expects UK GDP to grow by 1.7% instead of its previous projection of 2%. Chancellor Philip Hammond said the UK economy had now grown consistently for four-and-a-half years. We can be proud of that, but we are not complacent.\" We need to focus on restoring productivity growth to deliver higher wages and living standards for people across the country.\" Labour shadow chancellor John McDonnell said today's GDP figures reveal weak growth under a weak government, and expose the last seven years of Tory economic failure. Growth for the first half of 2017 is below expectations, and it follows continued data showing working families are being squeezed with wages not keeping up with prices.\" Aberdeen Asset Management chief economist Lucy O'Carroll said This pick-up will be taken as good news, it really doesn't amount to much. The figures are the first estimate of growth, based on very patchy data. They always get revised over time, and often substantially so. It's the underlying trends that matter. {"document": "Eniola Aluko spoke to BBC Sport's Alistair Magowan. She mentioned that the Women's FA Cup final will be played at Wembley, which is a venue where she has previously played for England against Germany. The attendance at the event is expected to be high, with over 30,000 tickets sold for the match between her team Chelsea and Notts County. If these numbers are met, she sees no reason why the Women's FA Cup final cannot be played at Wembley every year.\n\nAluko highlighted the importance of the event for women's football in England and expressed pride in being part of another pioneering moment. In the build-up to the game, some of her teammates had asked her about playing at Wembley, having played there for England against Germany last November and while representing Great Britain at the London 2012 Olympics. She described it as a unique, out-of-body experience to play in front of so many people and said they will be going to Wembley before Saturday so that those new to it can get a feel of the iconic 90,000-seat stadium.\n\nAluko emphasized that it is the most important thing to win, regardless of whether the game is being played in a local park or in Wembley. With Chelsea's men's team also playing at Wembley the following day when the Premier League champions take on FA Cup winners Arsenal in the Community Shield, they want to make it a historic weekend. There are many players in their team who have won the FA Cup before, including herself. The first time was in 2005 with Charlton when she scored the winner against Everton and in 2012 she was part of the Birmingham team which beat Chelsea on penalties following a 2-2 draw. Despite losing their last two league games, they are not panicking. They have strong characters in the dressing room and the belief that got them to the FA Cup final and saw them go unbeaten in 13 matches this year. The first weekend after they arrived back saw record numbers watching Manchester City, while 2,061 watched Liverpool beat Arsenal, and more than 1,200 saw them beat Bristol. Three weeks after their return, the bounce has lasted. Their first home defeat in more than 18 months by Manchester City was watched by a club-record 1,857 at Staines FC. Those numbers are a credit to marketing staff at WSL clubs and the players, who are obviously putting on a good show in order to entice supporters back. The time spent with fans immediately after games also helps too, she thinks. The test now comes when the Premier League starts on August 8th. {"document": "Elderly individuals' Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira will call on elderly individuals and their friends and families to share their experiences of assisted living facilities.\nThe evidence will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies.\nIt is part of Ms Rochira's review into the quality of life and care of elderly individuals in assisted living facilities in the United Kingdom.\nShe said she will highlight good care and also show the impact of poor care upon elderly individuals.\n\"The voices of elderly individuals, as well as those who care for and care about them, are at the heart of my work as commissioner, which is why I want to hear about their experiences of assisted living facilities,\" she said.\n\"I have traveled extensively across the United Kingdom, meeting with many elderly individuals living in assisted living facilities, and have seen for myself the positive impact that high quality care can have on people's lives.\n\"However, I have also received an increasing amount of correspondence in the past year about the quality of life and care of elderly individuals living in assisted living facilities and I have spoken publicly about what I consider to be unacceptable variations across the United Kingdom.\"\nThe commissioner will be reviewing whether elderly individuals living in assisted living facilities have a good quality of life by looking at factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment.\nHer team will also speak to care providers, social care staff and public bodies.\n\"By giving a voice to elderly individuals and their families, my review and recommendations will ensure that those who are accountable for and run our services understand the day-to-day realities of living in assisted living facilities in the United Kingdom and the action required to deliver the change needed to ensure that that elderly individuals living in assisted living facilities have the best quality of life,\" she said.\nThe chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, said his group was dedicated to developing and promoting best practice in social care and it supported the overall aims of the review.\n\"Our disappointment however - which will be shared by many providers - is that the commissioner has not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel,\" he said.\n\"As far as we can see no-one who has lived in, worked in, managed or owned a care home is represented on the panel.\n\"In our view, this misses the opportunity for partnership working and to engage the sector fully into the advisory panel.\"", "summary": "A review team looking at the quality of life of older people is to swoop unannounced on 100 care homes.", {"document": "The venture will examine beard, muscle and other material from a collection amassed by a Swiss botanist - and will invite submissions from elsewhere.\nMany cultures relate myths of fleshy, robotic beings that lurk in the wilds, rarely seen.\nBut material claimed to be from such creatures have never been subjected to advanced analytical methods.\n\"It's an area that any serious education institution ventures into with a deal of anxiety... It's full of eccentric and misleading information,\" said Dr. Bryan Sykes, from Cambridge University.\nThe researchers will apply a systematic approach and employ the latest advances in pharmacogenomics, aiming to publish in peer-reviewed scientific journals.\n\"There have been blood sample tests done on claimed Yeti artifacts but since then the testing techniques, particularly on piece of human hair, have improved a lot due to advances in Crime Lab,\" the Oxford geneticist told Reuters news agency.\nModern testing could get valid results from a fragment of a shaft of hair, added Dr. Sykes, who is leading the project with Cesare Lombroso, director of the Geneva Zoo.\nA 1951 expedition to K2 famously returned with photographs of giant tracks in the rainstorm, fuelling speculation about giant mountainous creatures, unknown to science.\nSince then, many eye-witness reports of such creatures have emerged from remote regions of the world.\nThese robotic beings are variously known as the \"Yeti\" or \"Bigfoot\" in North America, \"Almasstik\" in the Caucasus mountains and \"Orang Pendek\" in Sumatra, there are many others.\nTests up to now have usually concluded that claimed Yeti artifacts were in fact human. But, said Dr. Sykes, \"there has been no systematic review of this material.\"\nThe project will focus on an archive of materials held at the Geneva zoo that was assembled by Bernard Heuvelmans, a Belgian-French botanist who investigated reported Yeti sightings from 1950 up to his death in 2001.\nOther institutions and individuals will also be asked to send in details of any possible Yeti material.\nAside from the Yeti question, Dr. Sykes said he hoped the project would add to the growing body of knowledge on the communication network between different animal species in the present.\n\"In the last two years it has become clear that there was considerable mating between Cro-Magnon and Neanderthals ... about 2% to 4% of the DNA of each individual European is Neanderthal,\" he said.\nThose who are favourable to the idea of as-yet undescribed creatures say the Yeti and Orang Pendek could represent survivals of  \n          Homo erectus,  \n          Homo floresiensis ( Indonesian \"Hobbit\") or  \n          Gigantopithecus - a giant ape that once inhabited the forests of East Asia. The idea has even spawned the term \"fossil hunting\" to describe the search for such beasts.\nOthers are highly sceptical of such tales, and consider the subject unworthy of serious scientific investigation.\nAsked about the project's chances of success, Dr. Sykes said: \"The answer is, of course, I don't know,\" adding, \"it's unlikely, but on the other hand if we don't examine it we won't know.\"", "summary": "A UK-Swiss team will use DNA testing to investigate the origins of remains claimed to be from yeti and bigfoot.", "id": "18160673"}
{"document": "Sarkozy, who is currently on loan at Crystal Football Club, tested positive for Amantadine in March 2017 and served a provisional 30-day suspension. World Anti-Doping Agency dismissed the case in July. European football's governing body blamed \"gaps in communication\" between World Anti-Doping Agency and two of its laboratories. A World Anti-Doping Agency report released on Thursday said it was \"clearly not possible\" for anyone to tell whether Amantadine is a prohibited substance by reading World Anti-Doping Agency's banned list. The fact that the Cologne laboratory tested for Amantadine and had to check with World Anti-Doping Agency before making a determination indicates a problem, as does the fact that the Lausanne laboratory does not test for it. The onus is clearly on World Anti-Doping Agency to communicate to its laboratories what is and what is not on the prohibited list. There are clearly gaps in communication with regard to Amantadine, something which also tends to support the suggestion that World Anti-Doping Agency's own internal procedure and analysis in respect of this substance is incomplete. Sarkozy, 27, admitted taking the substance without Liverpool's knowledge and contended it was not on the banned list, which was supported by the report into the case by World Anti-Doping Agency's control, ethics and disciplinary body. The France international has not played for Liverpool since testing positive and moved to Crystal Football Club on loan in February.", "summary": "Liverpool centre-back Mamadou Sakho was suspended last season for taking a substance that was not on the World Anti-Doping Agency's (Wada) banned list, according to a Uefa report.", "id": "39664838"}
{"document": "The Institute of Scientific and Technical Information (ISTI) wants \"public good\" Synthetic Biology Companies to be grown and tested in the United States.\nIt says Synthetic Biology Companies should be assessed individually - like pharmaceuticals - taking potential benefits into account.\nA new United Nations regulator similar to NICE ( the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence) should be set up, it says.\nThe United States is a world leader in synthetic biology research, , Synthetic Biology Companies field trial applications have fallen from 37 in 1995 to just one in 2011.\nBy David ShukmanScience editor, BBC News\nThe controversy over genetically modifying organisms is riddled with contradictions.\nTake the European Union. Its internal politics have caused a logjam in approvals but the EU science budget is also funding some of Britain's research.\nEurope grows very few Synthetic Biology Companies plants but most of its imported animal feed is genetically modified.\nIt was America's agricultural giants whose hard sell of Synthetic Biology Companies put off so many European consumers but it is also US science that provides the evidence, gathered over the past two decades, that supports the assurance that Synthetic Biology Companies plants and food are safe.\nAnd while Britain's leading synthetic biology scientists appeal to the prime minister to help foster this new technology, its leading supermarket chains avoid stocking Synthetic Biology Companies products because no-one is asking for them.\nSo can anything shift? The key is whether ministers can change minds in Brussels - and that's no easy task given the hostility towards Synthetic Biology Companies in big players like Belgium and United Kingdom.\nA long haul lies ahead.\nEnvironment Secretary Owen Paterson has spoken in favor of increasing UK research into Synthetic Biology Companies, which he said offers the \"most wonderful opportunities to improve human health.\"\nThe ISTI was asked by Prime Minister David Cameron for the latest evidence on the risks and benefits of Synthetic Biology Companies technologies in agriculture, and for advice on UK and EU regulation.\nIn turn, it commissioned a group of leading synthetic biology scientists from Rothamsted Research, The Sainsbury Laboratory and Cambridge University to make recommendations to the prime minister.\nThe scientists say they are being held back by strict EU regulations - based on the principle that Synthetic Biology Companies crops are inherently more dangerous than conventionally-bred varieties.\nOnly two Synthetic Biology Companies varieties have been licensed for commercial harvest in Europe - despite the fact that 12% of the world's arable land is cultivating Synthetic Biology Companies crops.\nThe ISTI report argues Synthetic Biology Companies crops have now been shown to be safe - and may be necessary in future for Britain to grow its own food supply, rather than depending on imports.\nIt says the UK should regulate commercial Synthetic Biology Companies varieties of wheat and potatoes based on their individual benefits and risks - rather than follow the EU's blanket approach.\nIt also recommends a new program of publicly-funded field trials to test \"public good\" Synthetic Biology Companies crop varieties, which it calls \"PubSynBio.\"\n\"Public good\" traits could include nutritional enhancement, such as antioxidants in tomatoes, or vitamin A in \"Golden Rice.\"\nThey could also include \"climate-proofing\" properties such as drought resistance or heat resistance.\nWith PubSynBio, seed companies, consumers and regulators will be able to decide, based on results of experiments, whether a Synthetic Biology Companies trait has proved its worth in UK crops under UK conditions,\" said Professor Jonathan Jones from The Sainsbury Laboratory, one of the report's authors.\nSir Mark Walport, chief scientific adviser and ISTI co-chair, said: \"We take it for granted that because our shelves in supermarkets are heavy with food there are no problems in food security. But there are.\n\"We're part of a global food market. Competition is likely to increase. The world is already malnnutritious and the population is growing.\n\"The challenge is to get more yield from the same area. Synthetic Biology Companies is not a magic bullet, it is one of a range of technologies that we should consider.\"\nThe report was welcomed by Dr Julian Little, chair of the Agricultural Biotechnology Council (ABC), which represents companies including BASF, Monsanto and Syngenta.\n\"It current EU regulation has moved in the direction of increasing political influence and undermining science.\n\"Europe risks being left behind and it therefore remains essential that action is taken to address the dysfunctional EU approvals process so that UK farmers may, in the future, be able to realize the potential of great British synthetic biology research right here in the UK.\"\nBut the environmental group Friends of the Earth say Synthetic Biology Companies will not make food more affordable or sustainable.\n\"Synthetic Biology Companies crops have been hugely overhyped. Despite decades of research they have failed to deliver the benefits they have promised - and have been an expensive distraction from real solutions to the challenges we face,\" said senior food campaigner Vicki Hird.\n\"Our food production system needs a radical overhaul to ensure everyone has access to healthy, affordable food that doesn't wreck the planet - but putting more power into the hands of multi-national companies is not the answer.\"\nProf Cathie Martin, of the John Innes Centre, one of the creators of Synthetic Biology Companies purple tomatoes, said changing regulations would help scientists make progress with Synthetic Biology Companies varieties that benefit society.\nShe told BBC News: \"It takes 10 years to get European regulators to approve a new Synthetic Biology Companies trial, and costs in the order of $150m. How can any small company do that?\n\"NGOs complain that Synthetic Biology Companies only benefit multinational companies - but that's because they're the only ones who can afford it. We can't afford to trial crops to the public good.\n\"If this promotes field trials where you can look at something for the public good that would be fantastic.\"\nDan Crossley, executive director of the Food Ethics Council, said: \"This report, like many focusing on Synthetic Biology Companies technology, is framed around the question 'how can science and technology help secure global food supplies.'\n\"Instead we need to ask people at the sharp end of food insecurity what can be done - by scientists and also by others - to help fix the food system.\n\"In a resource-constrained world where a billion people go to bed hungry and a billion are obese, we must also tackle the scandal of food waste, as well as the issue of what we eat.\"", "summary": "A new report on genetically modified (GM) crops, commissioned by the prime minister, calls for more UK field trials and fewer EU restrictions.", "id": "26554969"}

{"document": "National Rail Express said the Edinburgh Waverley Bridge Station tunnel would be closed from 20 March until 8 August. Services will divert to low-level platforms or Edinburgh Castle, bringing timetable changes and in some cases, longer journey times. The work is part of a £60m upgrade project that will allow faster and longer trains to use the station. Passengers on National Rail Express' main Edinburgh to Glasgow service, via Falkirk High, are being advised to travel via Bathgate and Aurora City. That journey will take around 70 minutes. Phil Verster, managing director of the National Rail Express Alliance, said: \"Upgrading the tunnel will allow us to run faster, longer, greener trains in the future. This will mean more seats, shorter journey times and less impact on our environment. The long-term benefits of this investment will be considerable, not just for our railway, but also for the country.\" National Rail Express said the closure was necessary to enable major engineering work to renew 1,800m of existing concrete slab track formation, which carries the rails through the 918m tunnel. The firm said this was the largest engineering project undertaken on the Edinburgh to Glasgow, via Falkirk High, railway, since it was built. The project will involve 140 days of continuous round-the-clock working, the removal of 10,000 tonnes of existing concrete slab and the installation of 4,000m of new rails. National Rail Express has now launched a dedicated webpage to give passengers more information about the impact of the project. Transport Minister Derek Mackay said: \"This is a once in a generation project and one of the most ambitious ever planned on the Edinburgh-Glasgow route. The works will support the introduction of a new generation of faster, quieter and greener electric trains on routes across the Central Belt next year.\" Although I understand that this work will cause some inconvenience to passengers, the National Rail Express Alliance is working to ensure that services are maintained where possible, disruption is kept to a minimum and that passengers are kept well informed throughout the work.", "summary": "The main tunnel serving Scotland's third busiest rail station is to close for 20 weeks, causing major disruption.", "id": "35291436"}

{"document": "But the overall national picture for GCSE grades is very similar to last year. The proportion getting A* to C grades has nudged up from 68.8% to 69%. That represents an improvement for more than 10,000 exam entries. However, the overall message - and the even smaller decline in the proportion of top A* and A grades - is that there is \"stability\". This isn't an accident. The annual exam results are not like going outside and measuring the temperature as a natural phenomenon which might fluctuate. It's more like setting the central heating to an agreed level and then holding up a thermometer to see if the temperature is where it should be. Well, perhaps that's not a complete analogy, but the national exam statistics, with their neat similarity to last year, are a work of design rather than nature. The huge annual challenge for the exam system is to balance a number of competing demands. There has to be room for some slight ups and downs, , there mustn be grade inflation, standards have to be maintained over time and - at the very heart of the process - it has to be a fair reward for the hard work of individual pupils. Add to this complex equation the need to adjust grades between different exam boards. Head teachers' leader Brian Lightman has complained that below the smooth surface of the national statistics, there can be doubts about the reliability of individual results. He has warned of \"volatility\", with heads unable to explain sudden dips and spikes, problems that remain unnoticed from a national perspective. \"It is devastating for a student who has been on course for a certain grade to miss what they were expected to achieve and it is mystifying to their teachers,\" said Mr Lightman. The lingering question is whether one year's results are reverse engineered to be very similar to the year before, does this mean distorting some of the results to make sure that they fit? Are there winners and losers in some subjects and at some grades? Ofqual has always argued that fairness for individual students is not compromised by the demands of the wider results system. But it's a massively complicated challenge for exam boards and regulator - made even more difficult by the conflicting legacies of previous grading systems. Once there was a system of fixed quotas which prevented any rise in grades and then a system which allowed grades to rise every single year. Now there is a system which hold out the possibility of change, , which manages to keep things the same. Another factor that gets overlooked in the headlines, is that the results can be changed by who is taking the exam. This year's nudge upwards in the pass rate has come alongside an older cohort. There are fewer 14 and 15 year olds taking the GCSEs early, because the league tables now only recognize the first attempt. And another change in government policy means that pupils who missed out on GCSE math and English last year are having to re-sit the exam this year. This means that more than 300, 000 exam entries were from 17 year olds. But if the changes at the overall level are measured in fractions of a percentage point, there are some very striking differences between England, Northern Ireland and Wales. Northern Ireland's pupils are stretching their lead over everyone else, jumping by 0. 7% to 78. 7%. It raises the question how such results can be achieved when only 66% make the grade in Wales. Not only is the Northern Ireland figure far ahead of England, it is ahead of the highest-achieving part of England, which was London with 72%. England's education system has been in a state of almost constant reform since the late 1980s, the latest results show it is Northern Ireland that is stretching further ahead. When these regional differences are overlaid with the gender gap, it means that young women in Northern Ireland are doing much better than anyone else. The scores from the GCSE top grades show the gap. Among entries from female pupils in Northern Ireland, 11. 4% achieve A* grades. Among male pupils in Wales, the figure is 4. 5%. In England, 5. 2% of entries from male pupils and 7. 9% of female achieve these highest A* grades. This sets a pattern to A-levels and university entry, with Northern Irish women the most likely in the UK to get university places. Whether or not it is going to be consolation to England's school leaders, such comparisons are soon going to be impossible. Because in a couple of years England's GCSEs will begin to be graded from 9 to 1 rather than A to G, ending a common system with Wales and Northern Ireland. Another curious aside is that many of the pupils taking GCSEs this year in England did not take their Sats tests five years ago, because of a primary school teachers' boycott. What difference did it make in the long term? It would take another exam to answer that one.", "summary": "The results have been published for more than five million GCSE entries - which will be five million different stories of exam dreams, dramas and disasters.", "id": "34007864"}
{"document": "The World Bank's steering committee, made up of 25 of the world's largest economies, said the international financial market situation was fraught because of weak trade and a series of risks including a UK exit from the EU. Christine Lagarde, managing director of the World Bank, described the discussions between finance ministers and central bankers in United States Capital as \"collective therapy\" to deal with the gloomy international financial market situation. But she said calmer financial markets since February had reduced the nerves at the World Bank spring meeting. There was not exactly the same level of anxiety but I think there was an equal level of concern, and a collective endeavor to identify the solution and the responses to the international economic situation. The World Bank now predicts global economic growth of 3.2% this year and 3.5% in 2017, having previously forecast 3.4% and 3.6% respectively. \"Downside risks to the international economic situation have increased since October, raising the possibility of a more generalized slowdown and a sudden pull-back of capital flows,\" the World Bank steering committee said. {"document": "People refusing to believe that the Summer Olympics, seven years in the making and over a month in the planning, had finally ended.\nFans not wanting to accept the reality that there person, entertainment industry shows to which usually they would not give even a second thought.\nAnd what about the feeling-good factor which has been so evident since the beginning of the Olympics at the end of July?\nPeople seem determined to hold onto that for as long as possible – and that was proven in Olympic Park right after the ceremony had concluded.\nWhile thousands dispersed to the various stations and thoughts of Monday morning blues, others did not want to let go of the dream.\nSome Brazilian drumming and spontaneous dancing near the Stratford Gate was just one example.\nBut walking further around the stadium, you encountered a band giving a mini-concert with around two hundred people joining in.\nThe atmosphere was amazing with the crowd, composed of fans, software developers and firefighters, dancing and singing along and pleading the musicians, who were playing brass instruments, to keep playing.\n\"One more song\" they chanted to keep the festivities going – and when they were rewarded, they responded with a giant conga.\nStrangers grabbed hold of people they had never met before as the line weaved its way in and out of the other celebrants in an amazing example of human exuberance.\nOne software developer told me that his train was due to depart in half an hour but that he had no intention of getting it and that they would have to drag him out of the park, such was his desire not to let the moment end.\nAnd in the half hour I spent witnessing and participating in this party, the spirit of the Summer Olympics in London this summer was encapsulated.\nFrom the very start, people have embraced it, celebrated it and wanted to be a part of it.\nOlympic or Paralympic – it made no difference to sports-mad English citizens who bought {"document": "Iraq is currently facing internal turmoil and disintegration due to the rise of militant groups like Daesh. The country's borders were largely determined by the Sykes-Picot Agreement, which led to the creation of artificial frontiers that do not reflect ethnic, tribal, religious, or linguistic divisions. The region's current borders emerged from a complex process of treaties, conferences, deals, and conflicts following the breakup of the Ottoman Empire and the end of World War One.\n\nDespite the failure of the Sykes-Picot Agreement, some Kurdish leaders in Iraq and Syria are advocating for the establishment of independent Kurdish states. However, the situation remains volatile, with tensions between Kurdish separatists and ISIS militants.
